het_991.pun_sense: especially of a ship's lines etc
het_991.alter_sense: an act that violates the rules of a sport
het_991.human_text: Baseball players have to stay in line or they will be afoul of the rules .
het_991.human_explanation: Afoul means conflict, so baseball players have to stay in line or they'll be in conflict with the rules. A foul ball in baseball is a ball that is out of play when it lands. The word "afoul" has "foul" in it, a term used in baseball. The joke is playing on the word afoul.

het_990.pun_sense: speak dogmatically; state as a dogma
het_990.alter_sense: a member of the genus Canis (probably descended from the common wolf) that has been domesticated by man since prehistoric times; occurs in many breeds
het_990.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. A beagle is a breed of dog.  To 'dogmatize' something is to represent it as an incontrovertible truth.

het_987.pun_sense: spice from dried unopened flower bud of the clove tree; used whole or ground
het_987.human_text: Even covered in salad dressing my lettuce looked bare , so I put some cloves on it .
het_987.human_explanation: The person put salad dressing (dressing here is to be interpreted as clothes) on the lettuce. But it needed more clothes. Cloves sounds close to the word clothes.

het_982.human_text: The killer followed the psychopath into the forest where he was surrounded by the copse .
het_982.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. 'Copse' means a small group of trees. The word sounds identical to 'cops' which is a slang term to refer to police officers. The people are criminals and in the woods, so either meaning could be true.

het_980.pun_sense: a person who professes beliefs and opinions that he or she does not hold in order to conceal his or her real feelings or motives
het_980.alter_sense: electronic equipment that converts sound into electrical signals that can be transmitted over distances and then converts received signals back into sounds
het_980.human_text: Someone who attempts long distance fraud is known as a phony .
het_980.human_explanation: Long distance fraud can occur on the phone. Scammers that live far away from the people they are scamming will make a phone call to a victim, lie, then ask for money. "Phony" means fraudulent, but can also replace the suffix "-phone" which relates to sound. "Phone" is not only a suffix, but a communication device that allows for long distance communication. The joke is playing on the word phony, how it sounds close to 'phone' and long distance fraud.

het_978.pun_sense: in essence; at bottom or by one's (or its) very nature
het_978.alter_sense: a popular programming language that is relatively easy to learn; an acronym for beginner's all-purpose symbolic instruction code; no longer in general use
het_978.human_text: ' ' This is the most common language used on micros , ' ' said Tom basically .
het_978.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. To say something 'basically' is to say it in a simple way.  'BASIC' however, is the name of a family of general-purpose, high-level programming languages designed for ease of use.

het_973.pun_sense: solid-hoofed herbivorous quadruped domesticated since prehistoric times
het_973.alter_sense: deep and harsh sounding as if from shouting or illness or emotion; ; ; ; - Virgil Thomson
het_973.human_text: He doesn ' t talk much does he ? He ' s just a little horse .
het_973.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "horse".  Horses don't talk and "horse" sounds like "hoarse", which is when your throat is scratchy and you can't speak.

het_958.pun_sense: a laminated metamorphic rock similar to granite
het_958.alter_sense: pleasant or pleasing or agreeable in nature or appearance; - George Meredith
het_958.human_text: Upon being shown a uniquely sculptured piece of so - called granite , a geologist remarked to his colleague ' ' You know that ' s really gneiss . ' '
het_958.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  'Gneiss' is the name of another type of metamorphic rock.  'Gneiss' sounds like 'nice', so in a sentence it sounds like the geologist is complimented the craftsmanship of the sculpture, but they're actually saying it's a different type of rock.

het_956.alter_sense: pass from physical life and lose all bodily attributes and functions necessary to sustain life
het_956.human_text: OLD HAIRDRESSERS never dye . . . or cut .
het_956.human_explanation: This joke gets extra credit for breaking the formula. To 'dye' hair means to color it, while 'dying' means to pass on. The listner realizes the alternate 'dye' that is used here (as in to color, not pass away), when they hear 'or cut'.

het_955.pun_sense: an actor who communicates entirely by gesture and facial expression
het_955.human_text: They were the quietest burglars in the history of New York City . The newspapers called them ' Criminal Mimes . '
het_955.human_explanation: Criminal Mimes' is similar to the show 'Criminal Minds' about organized crime. Mimes are performers that are usally completely silent. So the joke is that the burglars were very quiet like mimes.

het_952.alter_sense: a musical note having the time value of an eighth of a whole note
het_952.human_text: ' ' I have to sing a run of eighth notes , ' ' said Tom quaveringly .
het_952.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "quaveringly" means to speak in a quivering voice but "quaver" is a term for an eighth of a note in music.

het_95.pun_sense: the part of the body between the neck and the upper arm; push with the shoulders; carry a burden, either real or metaphoric
het_95.alter_sense: serve as a soldier in the military
het_95.human_text: A young corporal dislocated his arm during a battle but kept going . You could say he was shouldering on .
het_95.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The phrase "soldiering on" means to continue to do something even though it is difficult but "soldiering" sounds like "shouldering" refering to part of the body connected to the body. Here, "shouldering on" means carrying on despite the soldier having an injured shoulder.

het_943.alter_sense: be brought to or as if to the point of death by an intense emotion such as embarrassment, amusement, or shame
het_943.human_text: When an actress saw her first strands of gray hair she thought she ' d dye .
het_943.human_explanation: Dye is a substance that adds color to something else. Die means to stop living. "Dye" sounds like "die". Sometimes when people see markers of aging, they "want to die" which means they're just really upset and freaking out. This joke is referring to hair, so dye can be understood literally. The actress is thinking of dying her hair. Or, it can be understood as the actress was extremely upset and "thought she'd die".

het_940.pun_sense: a substance used as a coating to protect or decorate a surface (especially a mixture of pigment suspended in a liquid); dries to form a hard coating; dry coloring material (especially a powder to be mixed with a liquid to produce paint, etc.)
het_940.human_text: When artists dream in color it ' s a pigment of their imagination .
het_940.human_explanation: "Pigment of their imagination" sounds close to the common saying "figment of their imagination". If something is a figment of your imaginaion, then that something was imagined. Pigment refers to the color of something. Artists are people that create paintings, drawings, sculputors or pieces using extensive colors, or pigments. The word "pigment" was used in place of "figment" when discussing an artist dreaming in color. Color refers to pigment. This joke is a play on the word pigment.

het_94.pun_sense: a hollow globule of gas (e.g., air or carbon dioxide); form, produce, or emit bubbles
het_94.human_text: The inventor of chewing gum soon bubbled his money .
het_94.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "bubbled" refers to making a bubble with chewing gum but sounds like "doubled" meaning to increase by twice the original amount.

het_935.pun_sense: indulging with temperance; with indifference or without dejection; without good reason
het_935.human_text: ' ' This Bud ' s for you , ' ' said Tom lightly .
het_935.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. 'Bud' is referring to 'Bud Light' a brand of beer.  To say something 'lightly' means to say it softly or quietly.

het_934.pun_sense: in an appealing but bold manner
het_934.alter_sense: a vulcanized rubber disk 3 inches in diameter that is used instead of a ball in ice hockey
het_934.human_text: I love hockey , said Tom , puckishly .
het_934.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. In hockey, a puck is used to be hit into goals.  Tom says this 'puckishly', which means having or showing a desire to cause trouble in a playful or harmless way.

het_930.pun_sense: round red root vegetable; biennial Eurasian plant usually having a swollen edible root; widely cultivated as a food crop
het_930.alter_sense: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict; be superior
het_930.human_text: Cane sugar can ' t be beet .
het_930.human_explanation: This is a pun on "beet". The joke says that cane sugar can't be beat, which means that nothing can be better than cane sugar. The beat part is spelled like beet in reference to beet sugar. Cane sugar can't be "beet" because cane sugar and beet sugar are two different things.

het_924.pun_sense: marine colonial polyp characterized by a calcareous skeleton; masses in a variety of shapes often forming reefs; the hard stony skeleton of a Mediterranean coral that has a delicate red or pink color and is used for jewelry; of a strong pink to yellowish-pink color
het_924.alter_sense: related to or written for or performed by a chorus or choir
het_924.human_text: A group of singers wore coral necklaces .
het_924.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'coral' which in this case is initially referring to a type of necklace, but it's also being used because the alternative spelling of 'choral' sounds similar and refers to something composed for or sung by a choir or chorus.

het_923.pun_sense: in an uncontrolled or unrestrained manner
het_923.human_text: I wish I ' d said that , Oscar , said Tom wildly .
het_923.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "wildly" means spoken in a way that lacks restraint but "Wilde" is also the name of famous literary figure Oscar Wilde.

het_922.pun_sense: in a devout and pious manner
het_922.alter_sense: the ratio of the circumference to the diameter of a circle; approximately equal to 3.14159265358979323846...
het_922.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words. 'Piously' means marked by or showing reverence for deity and devotion to divine worship. The start of the word is 'pi' which is a symbol that stands for the ratio of the circumference of any circle to the diameter of that circle. The number spoken is the start of pi's decimal sequence.

het_913.pun_sense: a visual display of information; a visual representation of the relations between certain quantities, represented as points, plotted with reference to a set of axes
het_913.alter_sense: the practice of offering something (usually money) in order to gain an illicit advantage
het_913.human_text: The researcher ' s report showed data on the political graphed .
het_913.human_explanation: This is a pun on the term "political graft" and how researchers create and analyze graphs.

het_911.human_text: Ancient vessels lacked stability because there were no rudders in the days of yaw .
het_911.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "yaw". A yaw is a type of ship movement. "Yaw" is kinda similar to the "yore" in "days of yore", which means in the past. So the ancient ships were unstable back in the day when they would yaw because they had no rudders.

het_909.pun_sense: normal or customary activity of a person in a particular social setting; what something is used for
het_909.alter_sense: small rounded bread either plain or sweet
het_909.human_text: In a bakery buns usually play a small role .
het_909.human_explanation: A role is a part. Role sounds like roll. A roll is a piece of bread that is small. The buns, which are a type of bread, play a small role, as in, buns are small rolls.

het_908.pun_sense: the deliberate act of deviating from the truth; a deliberately false or improbable account
het_908.alter_sense: artifact made by weaving or felting or knitting or crocheting natural or synthetic fibers
het_908.human_text: The promises of some tailors are pure fabrication .
het_908.human_explanation: Those jerks! Tailors are fabricating, or lying about, what they can do with garments brought to them. Unfortunately, they don't work that well with their fabric.

het_907.pun_sense: any of various edible mushrooms of the genus Morchella having a brownish spongelike cap
het_907.alter_sense: concerned with principles of right and wrong or conforming to standards of behavior and character based on those principles
het_907.human_text: The mushroom is a vegetable of high morel standing .
het_907.human_explanation: This is a pun. "morel" is a type of edible fungi, which is related to mushrooms,  and sounds similar to "moral"

het_905.alter_sense: of or relating to menstruation or the menses
het_905.human_text: The king never let any of his personal musicians go swimming immediately after eating for fear that they would get minstrel cramps .
het_905.human_explanation: This joke doesn't really make much sense as a minstrel cramp is a play on the words "menstrual cramp" which doesn't really fit the conditions.

het_902.pun_sense: meat of edible aquatic invertebrate with a shell (especially a mollusk or crustacean)
het_902.alter_sense: concerned chiefly or only with yourself and your advantage to the exclusion of others; - Maria Weston Chapman
het_902.human_text: Some cooks have a shellfish attitude .
het_902.human_explanation: "Shellfish attitude" sounds like "selfish attitude". A selfish attitude is when one is concerned excessively or exclusively with oneself. Shellfish are a type of aquatic invertebrate that can be consumed at restaurants (these invertebrates include lobster, crabs, clams). The person getting referred to in the joke is a cook. Cooks can create seafood dishes with shellfish. This joke is a play on the word "shellfish".

het_900.pun_sense: the cardinal number that is the sum of one and one or a numeral representing this number
het_900.alter_sense: to a degree exceeding normal or proper limits
het_900.human_text: My friend gave me a book about puns for my birthday and I loved it . It was two meaningful .
het_900.human_explanation: Two meaningful refers to the fact that puns are jokes with double meanings. This pun is meta in the sense that it's about a pun, and two meaningful sounds like too meaningful, as in it's personal and contains deep meaning.

het_9.pun_sense: support consisting of a place to rest the foot while ascending or descending a stairway
het_9.human_text: Two construction workers had a stairing contest .
het_9.human_explanation: A stair is a set of steps. Stair sounds like stare.To stare at someone is to look at someone. A staring contest is a contest involving two people looking at each other without blinking. It's a common activity kids engage in when they're bored. Construction workers build stairs. The construction workers are having a stairing contest, or a contest involving stair building. This phrase can sound like the construction workers are having a staring contest. This joke is a play the word stair.

het_898.pun_sense: originally a person of noble birth trained to arms and chivalry; today in Great Britain a person honored by the sovereign for personal merit
het_898.human_text: When those around King Arthur ' s table had insomnia , there were a lot of sleepless knights .
het_898.human_explanation: Sleepless knights means that the knights with insomnia were not sleeping. "Sleepless knights" sounds like "sleepless nights" which is a term often used to express not sleeping at night. The joke is playing on the word "knights" because it sounds like "nights".

het_893.alter_sense: an employee of a bank who receives and pays out money
het_893.human_text: ' ' I work at a bank , ' ' said Tom tellingly .
het_893.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words.  A person who works at the desk at a bank is called a bank 'teller'.  To say something 'tellingly' is to say it with a striking or revealing effect; significantly.

het_889.alter_sense: the state of being free of suspicion
het_889.human_text: I was completely exonerated , said Tom clearly .
het_889.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "clearly" means without doubt but "cleared" also is a term that means charges have been lifted, which is what happens when someone is exonerated.

het_888.pun_sense: hard bonelike structures in the jaws of vertebrates; used for biting and chewing or for attack and defense
het_888.alter_sense: a fact that has been verified
het_888.human_text: A dentist has to tell a patient the whole tooth .
het_888.human_explanation: "The whole tooth" sounds like "the whole truth". A dentist is a type of professional that helps keep teeth healthy. Teeth is the plural of tooth. A tooth is an enamel coated structure located in the jaw of a mammal. The joke is replacing the word "truth" with "tooth" because they sound kind of similar, and it relates nicely to dentistry.

het_887.alter_sense: cause to be directed or transmitted to another place
het_887.human_text: The cheque is in the post , Tom assented .
het_887.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "assent" means an expression of approval or aggreement but "sent" means an item is in the mail or being delivered.

het_886.pun_sense: a person who requires medical care
het_886.alter_sense: good-natured tolerance of delay or incompetence
het_886.human_text: A pediatrician is a doctor of little patients .
het_886.human_explanation: A pediatrician is a doctor that treats people 21 years old or younger (so children, infants, teenagers). Little patients sounds like "little patience". When someone has "little patience" it means that they do not have a lot of tolerance for whining or delays. The text can be understood as the pediatrician treats young people, or that the pediatrician has little patience.

het_883.pun_sense: a cut of meat taken from the side and back of an animal between the ribs and the rump
het_883.alter_sense: get to know or become aware of, usually accidentally
het_883.human_text: She was only a Butcher ' s daughter , but there wasn ' t much more she could loin .
het_883.human_explanation: This is a pun that relies upon a New Yoik Accint.

het_881.pun_sense: the narrowing of the body between the ribs and hips
het_881.alter_sense: useless or profitless activity; using or expending or consuming thoughtlessly or carelessly
het_881.human_text: An hourglass is a waist of time .
het_881.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'waste of time' which is meant to mean a certain activity isn't worth the effort/ time you put into it. However, 'waist' is used in it's place because it sounds similar and because peope who have a curvy figure are said to be shapped like an hourglass

het_877.pun_sense: the act of propelling with force; propel with force
het_877.alter_sense: a midday meal; take the midday meal
het_877.human_text: Goddard couldn ' t be reached . He was out to launch .
het_877.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words. Robert H. Goddard is a physicist who is famous for liquid fueled rockets.  'Out to lunch' was changed to 'out to launch' because Goddard would likely attend a rocket launch.

het_874.alter_sense: home appliance consisting of a flat metal base that is heated and used to smooth cloth
het_874.human_text: OLD TAILORS never die , they just get ironic .
het_874.human_explanation: A tailor is a person that makes fitted clothes. An iron is used to smooth out wrinkles in clothing. We see the word "iron" in "ironic". Ironic refers to something happening in the opposite way of what was expected, causing amusement. The joke selectively used the word ironic to explain what happens to tailors when they get older.

het_872.pun_sense: the largest ocean in the world; relating to or bordering the Pacific Ocean
het_872.human_text: The fisherman kept bragging about the big fish he caught , but he would not be very pacific about where he caught it .
het_872.human_explanation: Pacific is the name of an ocean. An ocean is where you can catch fish. "Pacific" sounds close to "specific". Since the joke is discussing a fishman catching fish, the word "specific" was replaced with "pacific" which relates to an ocean where fish can be found. The joke is playing on the word "pacific" because it sounds close to "specific".

het_871.pun_sense: long coarse hair growing from the crest of the animal's neck
het_871.human_text: Lions don ' t have to worry about every little detail in life . . . just the mane thing .
het_871.human_explanation: This is a pun on "mane". The joke is saying that lions only worry about the main thing, as in the thing as a whole, or the most important part. Main is spelled like "mane" because male lions have manes, which are tufts of fur around their head and neck.

het_870.pun_sense: an edge tool used to cut and shape wood
het_870.alter_sense: make an addition (to); join or combine or unite with others; increase the quality, quantity, size or scope of; constitute an addition
het_870.human_text: Having too many axe - like tools to do a particular job only adze to the confusion .
het_870.human_explanation: It's not common knowledge that an 'adze' is a bladed cutting tool. That's why the pun falls flat, like a tree that's just been cut down with a blade :/.

het_87.pun_sense: a performer who juggles objects and performs tricks of manual dexterity
het_87.alter_sense: a vital part that is vulnerable to attack; veins in the neck that return blood from the head
het_87.human_text: To kill a circus in one blow , go for the juggler .
het_87.human_explanation: A juggler is an entertainer that tosses several objects up into the air and catches them. Juggler sounds like "jugular" which is an adjective meaning of the throat. Jugular is also known to be short for "jugular vein" which is an important vein found in the neck. If the jugular vein is cut, a person can bleed out and die. The joke is saying that in order to kill a circus in one blow, go for the juggler which sounds like jugular. The joke is a play on the word juggler.

het_867.alter_sense: an average of n numbers computed by adding some function of the numbers and dividing by some function of n
het_867.human_text: ' ' It ' s only average , ' ' said Tom meanly .
het_867.human_explanation: A play on the words average and mean. Average is used both as the mathematics term and an assessement of attractiveness. Mean is used both as the mathatics term and speaking with derision.

het_864.alter_sense: cause to be directed or transmitted to another place
het_864.human_text: ' ' I ' ve mailed the letter , ' ' Tom assented .
het_864.human_explanation: The joke doesn't work because the meaning of 'assent' doesn't make sense in this context.

het_863.pun_sense: food or meals in general; a committee having supervisory powers
het_863.alter_sense: uninterested because of frequent exposure or indulgence
het_863.human_text: Do hotel managers get board with their jobs ?
het_863.human_explanation: I think the joke is a pun.  Do hotel managers have a board for room vacancies? It might be a reference to the phrase 'room and board'. Regardless, the word 'bored' as in 'boredom' has been replaced with 'board' as in 'room and board'.

het_861.alter_sense: strips of potato fried in deep fat
het_861.human_text: The British cannibal enjoyed snacking on fish and chaps .
het_861.human_explanation: "Fish and chaps" sounds close to "fish and chips" which is a popular British dish that is composed of fish and french fries. Chaps is another word for man, or boy. A cannibal is a mammal that consumes its own species, in this case a human that eats humans. This joke is playing on the popular dish "fish and chips" except "chips" was replaced with "chaps" because the joke is talking about a cannibal.

het_859.alter_sense: exhaust or get tired through overuse or great strain or stress; exhaust or get tired through overuse or great strain or stress
het_859.human_text: He cussed in his sleep all night and woke up all swore out .
het_859.human_explanation: "All swore out" sounds like "all wore out" which means exhausted, or spent. "Swore" was used in place of "wore" because they are close sounding. The person was exhausted because of swearing. Swearing is cussing. Swore is the past tense of swearing.

het_851.pun_sense: a straight line that intersects a curve at two or more points
het_851.alter_sense: 1/60 of a minute; the basic unit of time adopted under the Systeme International d'Unites; an indefinitely short time
het_851.human_text: I finished my trigonometry exam without a secant to lose .
het_851.human_explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'without a second to lose' meaning you completed a task using every minute of the alotted time. However, 'secant' is used in place of 'second' because it sounds similar and because 'secant' refers to the ratio of the hypotenuse to the shorter side adjacent to an acute angle (in a right-angled triangle); the reciprocal of a cosine, which I'm guessing is realted to trigonometry (I never took it)

het_849.pun_sense: the period during which a monarch is sovereign
het_849.alter_sense: water falling in drops from vapor condensed in the atmosphere
het_849.human_text: Britain is a wet place since the queen has had a long reign .
het_849.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "reign". "Reign" means to rule. The Queen has ruled England for a long time, so she has had a "long reign". "Reign" sounds like "rain". In Britain it can be very rainy, which is why they say it is a wet place. So Britain has had a "long rain" as well as a "long reign" (of their queen).

het_848.pun_sense: a vibrator consisting of a thin strip of stiff material that vibrates to produce a tone when air streams over it
het_848.alter_sense: interpret something that is written or printed
het_848.human_text: I wanted to be a clarinettist but I couldn ' t reed music .
het_848.human_explanation: Read is a homophone of reed. To read means to comprehend the meaning of something by interpreting the characters seen. A reed is a part of the plant of grass. In order to produce sound in a clarinet, it needs a reed in the mouthpiece. "Couldn't reed music" sounds like "couldn't read music" meaning they couldn't understand the music they were looking at. "Read" was replaced with "reed" to reference the clarinet reed used in the mouthpiece. This joke is playing on the word "reed" becauase it sounds like "read".

het_844.pun_sense: any small opening in the skin or outer surface of an animal
het_844.human_text: If you say you have bad skin , I ' d say that was a pore excuse .
het_844.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. A 'pore' is a pocket in the skin where oils are let out. 'Pore' sounds like 'poor' which would make the phrase 'poor excuse', meaning that it is not a valid reason.

het_837.pun_sense: strong green liqueur flavored with wormwood and anise
het_837.alter_sense: the time interval during which something or somebody is away
het_837.human_text: Drinking too much of a certain potent potable may require a leave of absinthe .
het_837.human_explanation: Absinthe is supposed to sound like absence. The joke is referencing alcohol. Drinking too much alcohol may require you to be absent from work. Absinthe was used in place of absence because they sound similar. Absinthe is an alcoholic beverage though.

het_830.alter_sense: a lump or mass of hard consolidated mineral matter
het_830.human_text: You ' ll never conquer me , Goliath said stonily .
het_830.human_explanation: In the Bible, there is a story about a boy named David and a philistine giant named Goliath. David conquers goliath with some stones and a sling. Stonily means in an unfriendly way, without showing any emotion. This joke is centered on the word "stonily" because we hear the word "stone" in it, which relates to how David conquered Goliath.

het_825.pun_sense: (pathology) a small abnormal patch on or inside the body
het_825.human_text: A motorcycle rider with bad teeth is the leader of the plaque .
het_825.human_explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'leader of the pack' which is someone that is a leader or head of an organization, club, gang, etc, but 'plaque' is used in it's place because it sounds similar and because it refers to the sticky film of bacteria that constantly forms on teeth, which is what you'd get if you had bad teeth

het_822.pun_sense: a substance used as a coating to protect or decorate a surface (especially a mixture of pigment suspended in a liquid); dries to form a hard coating; dry coloring material (especially a powder to be mixed with a liquid to produce paint, etc.)
het_822.human_text: When you dream in color , it ' s a pigment of your imagination .
het_822.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words.  The word 'pigment' means a color, and sounds like 'figment' which in the phrase 'figment of your imagination' means it is an illusion made by one's own mind.

het_820.pun_sense: a male monarch or emperor (especially of Russia prior to 1917)
het_820.human_text: Before the revolution , Russia was in a Tsary state .
het_820.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. 'Tsary' is the word 'Tsar' changed to sound like 'sorry'.  'Tsar' was the title of the ruler of Russia before its revolution. Saying it was 'in a tsary state' makes it sound like it was in poor condition.

het_813.pun_sense: a feeling of strong sexual desire
het_813.human_text: His affection for her was more than a passion interest .
het_813.human_explanation: "A passing interest" means one that flees easily. Here, "passion," meaning affection, replaces "passing" instead

het_810.pun_sense: a periodic count of the population
het_810.alter_sense: the faculty through which the external world is apprehended
het_810.human_text: OLD POPULATION EXPERTS never die , they just lose their census .
het_810.human_explanation: A population expert might be someone who studies populations and demographics, which is information that is collected by a sensus. Sensus sounds like senses, and when someone loses their senses, it might be from old age.

het_807.pun_sense: the state of being pregnant; the period from conception to birth when a woman carries a developing fetus in her uterus

het_804.pun_sense: a roughly cylindrical vessel that is open at the top

het_783.pun_sense: edible subterranean fungus of the genus Tuber; any of various highly prized edible subterranean fungi of the genus Tuber; grow naturally in southwestern Europe

het_685.pun_sense: related to onions; white cylindrical bulb and flat dark-green leaves; plant having a large slender white bulb and flat overlapping dark green leaves; used in cooking; believed derived from the wild Allium ampeloprasum
het_685.alter_sense: the discharge of a fluid from some container; an accidental hole that allows something (fluid or light etc.) to enter or escape

het_685.human_explanation: A leek is a plant and can be grown in a garden. Leek is a homophone of leak. "Leak" is a word that describes a container slowly losing its contents, or it refers to the hole causing it. In this case, the garden hose is the item that has the leak. "I couldn't get to the leek without getting wet" can be understood as the person couldn't get to the plant without getting wet. het_681.alter_sense: a beloved person; used as terms of endearment
het_681.human_text: She was small , slender with doe like eyes . ' ' Oh , my deer , ' ' he whispered .
het_681.human_explanation: "Oh my deer" sounds like "oh my dear" except deer replaces dear. "Oh my dear" an expression used to express shock or concern. Doe like eyes means that someone has large, trusting eyes. A doe is a female deer.

het_678.pun_sense: a wooden or metal staff that fits under the armpit and reaches to the ground; used by disabled person while walking
het_678.human_text: I went to prom with a broken leg . During the slow dances my date could tell that I had a crutch on her .
het_678.human_explanation: "Crutch on her" sounds like "crush on her". To have a crush on someone is to have romantic feelings towards another. When someone's leg is broken, they are typically given a cast for their leg, and crutches to help them move about. A crutch is a long stick that helps support the body. So, the joke could be taken literally, as in this person's date is literally bearing the weight of a crutch. Or, because "crutch" sounds like "crush" the joke is saying "my date could tell that I had romantic feelings for her". The joke is playing on the phrase "crutch on her" because it sounds close to "crush on her".

het_676.pun_sense: paper cut to an appropriate size for writing letters; usually with matching envelopes
het_676.human_text: What is the best store to be in during an earthquake ? A stationery store .
het_676.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "stationery". A stationery store is a store for writing and office supplies. "Stationery" sounds like "stationary". "Stationary" means to stay still. In an earthquake, a store that does not shake will be the safest to be in.

het_672.pun_sense: uninterested because of frequent exposure or indulgence
het_672.human_text: At some executive meetings there is a chairman of the bored .
het_672.human_explanation: This is a play on words. A "chairman of the board" means the principal officer of a corporation but "bored" means feeling weary due to disinterest.

het_670.human_text: Opportunities take ' ' now ' ' for an answer
het_670.human_explanation: This is a pun on how now sounds like no and you need to take advantage of your opportunities now or they will go away.

het_665.pun_sense: sharp piercing cry; utter a sudden loud cry
het_665.alter_sense: project onto a screen for viewing; the display of a motion picture
het_665.human_text: I like the latest horror movie so much that I ' ve arranged a private screaming .
het_665.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words.  A 'private screening' would be a private showing of a film.  In a horror film, one might scream out of fear, so the phrase was changed to 'private screaming'.

het_662.human_text: The study of genealogy is a basic requirement for a descent education .
het_662.human_explanation: Descent sounds close to "decent" . The word descent describes the origin or background of a person in terms of their family. A "decent", or satisfactory education is what people often seek. Genealogy is the study of families and lineage tracing. The joke is playing on the word descent.

het_657.human_text: ' ' It ' s the quotient of two integers , ' ' said Tom rationally .
het_657.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. A 'rational' number in mathematics is a number that can be a quotient of two integers with no repeating decimal.  Being 'rational' or speaking 'rationally' means to do so calmly and by thinking things through.

het_656.pun_sense: a scar where the umbilical cord was attached
het_656.alter_sense: connected with or belonging to or used in a navy
het_656.human_text: He stared at his belly button so much , he was promoted to navel officer .
het_656.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "navel". The word "naval" has been replaced by the identical-sounding word "navel" because a "navel" is a belly button and this joke is about a guy who looks at his belly button.

het_653.pun_sense: a man who is the lover of a man or woman
het_653.human_text: Pink satin was perfect for her gown , yet the debutante appeared even more charming with beaux on either side .
het_653.human_explanation: Beaux refers to the debutante having multiple suitors, but is used also to sound like bows on the dress

het_65.alter_sense: that which is contrary to the principles of justice or law
het_65.human_text: By yourself you ' re in the right . In a group you ' re in the throng .
het_65.human_explanation: "Throng" sounds like "wrong". A throng is a pack of people. "In a group you're in the throng" which is correct, but also sounds like "in the group you're in the wrong" which is the opposite of "by yourself you're in the right".

het_647.pun_sense: of or relating to or characteristic of feudalism
het_647.alter_sense: unproductive of success; producing no result or effect
het_647.human_text: It is difficult to escape being a peasant because resistance is feudal .
het_647.human_explanation: The feudal system was a system that related to relationships that were derived from the holding of land in exchange for service or labor. Feudal sounds like futile. Futile means ineffective. Peasants work the land to exchange their labor for a place to stay.

het_645.pun_sense: a natural stream of water smaller than a river (and often a tributary of a river)
het_645.human_text: OLD RIVER RATS never die , they just start to creek
het_645.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "creek". Creeks are like rivers and this joke is about river rats. Creek sounds like creak which means to show weakness or frailty under strain, as someone who is old and dying might do.

het_643.pun_sense: strength of mind that enables one to endure adversity with courage
het_643.alter_sense: the cardinal number that is the product of ten and four; being ten more than thirty
het_643.human_text: ' ' I bought myself fifty hamburgers and I ' ve only ten left , ' ' said Tom with fortitude .
het_643.human_explanation: forty is in the word fortitude which also how  many was gone

het_64.alter_sense: German baroque organist and contrapuntist; composed mostly keyboard music; one of the greatest creators of western music (1685-1750)
het_64.human_text: ' ' I ' ve been listening to the Brandenburg Concertos , ' ' Tom barked .
het_64.human_explanation: Not completely sure, but is 'barked' supposed to sound close to Bach? Bach is the composer of the Brandenburg Concertos.

het_639.pun_sense: writes (books or stories or articles or the like) professionally (for pay)
het_639.alter_sense: something offered (as a proposal or bid); the verbal act of offering
het_639.human_text: When she made Mario Puzo ' s books required reading for her class , she made him an author they couldn ' t refuse .
het_639.human_explanation: Wordplay. Mario Puzo is the author of the novel that the famous film The Godfather is adapted from. A famous line from the movie involves one character saying that they will intimidate another into following their orders by "making him an offer he can't refuse". The pun is on the similarity in sound between "offer" and "author"; the students cannot refuse to read Puzo's works because he is required reading for the class.

het_635.pun_sense: (botany) the usually underground organ that lacks buds or leaves or nodes; absorbs water and mineral salts; usually it anchors the plant to the ground; dig with the snout
het_635.alter_sense: an established line of travel or access
het_635.human_text: Animals that tunnel in the soil have to have an escape root .
het_635.human_explanation: This is a play on the word route. A root refers to the part of a plant that is in the soil. A route is a course taken. The word root was used here to mean route, but root made sense because they're talking about animals in soil.

het_630.pun_sense: a usually secretive or illicit sexual relationship
het_630.human_text: A course offered to introduce French in five easy liaisons .
het_630.human_explanation: I think liasons is supposed to sound like "lessons". In French a liason is the pronunciation of a linking consonant between two words. Lessons refer to something learned or taught. This joke is playing on the word "liasons" because it sounds like "lessons".

het_629.pun_sense: a mixture containing two or more metallic elements or metallic and nonmetallic elements usually fused together or dissolving into each other when molten
het_629.alter_sense: an associate who provides cooperation or assistance
het_629.human_text: Two mining companies merged and became alloys .
het_629.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "allies" means people who work together or help each other in a given enterprise. But "allies" sounds like "alloys" meaning metals found in mines which are made from combining two or more metallic elements.

het_627.alter_sense: lack confidence in or have doubts about; consider unlikely or have doubts about
het_627.human_text: The weather man said there won ' t be any rain for 6 months , but I drought it .
het_627.human_explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'doubt it' which means a feeling of uncertainty or lack of conviction, but 'drought' is used in it's place because it kind of sounds similar and because a drought is what happens when it rains infrequently

het_624.alter_sense: the imperial dynasty of China from 1368 to 1644
het_624.human_text: ' ' Have you seen my collection of ancient Chinese artifacts ? ' ' asked Tom charmingly .
het_624.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "charmingly". "Charmingly" has the word "charm" in it. A charm can be an ancient Chinese artifact and the joke is about ancient Chinese artifacts.

het_622.pun_sense: a liquor made from fermented mash of grain
het_622.human_text: Making your own hard liquor is a whiskey business .
het_622.human_explanation: "Whiskey business" sounds like risky business. "Risky business" means that there is possibility of danger or failure or loss for a business. Whiskey is a type of hard liquor. "Making your own hard liquor is a whiskey business" can be understood literally, as in, you're in the business of making whiskey. Or, it can be understood as being risky, since "whiskey business" sounds like "risky business". The joke is playing on the word "whiskey".

het_619.pun_sense: an occasion (usually brief) for buying at specially reduced prices
het_619.alter_sense: travel on water propelled by wind
het_619.human_text: OLD STOREKEEPERS never die , they just sale away .
het_619.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  'Sale' sounds like 'sail', and both meanings are used here.  'Sale' refers to a promoted deal from a seller of some product or service.  'Sail' refers to sailing on water, and the phrase 'sail away' can mean to travel far away.

het_618.pun_sense: first day of the week; observed as a day of rest and worship by most Christians
het_618.alter_sense: ice cream served with a topping
het_618.human_text: We Are Not Dairy Queen  But We Have Great Sundays
het_618.human_explanation: "Sundays" is a homophone of "sundaes". Sundays is the plural of Sunday, which is a day in the week. Sundaes is the plural of sundae which is a type of dessert involving ice cream. A sundae typically has dairy as a main ingredient. A Dairy Queen is a fast food chain that serves ice cream. Tom is saying that they are not a Dairy Queen, but they have "great Sundays" meaning their Sundays are fun filled, but "great Sundays" sounds like "great sundaes", so "great ice cream". This joke is playing on the word Sundays and its homophone sundaes.

het_617.pun_sense: the official language of Finland; belongs to the Baltic Finnic family of languages; of or relating to or characteristic of Finland or the people of Finland
het_617.alter_sense: a highly developed state of perfection; having a flawless or impeccable quality; ; ; --Joseph Conrad
het_617.human_text: All students in Helsinki go to Finnish school .
het_617.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'finishing school' which is a private school where girls are prepared for entry into fashionable society, but 'Finnish' is used in it's place because it sounds slightly similar and since Helsinki is the capital of Finland, any school there is a Finnish school

het_612.alter_sense: not having a point especially a sharp point
het_612.human_text: ' ' My pencil is blunt , ' ' said Tom pointlessly .
het_612.human_explanation: Pencils that are sharp have a sharp point at the end. For something to be pointless is for something to be without direction. Pointless can also be understood literally, something without a point. This joke is a play on the word point.

het_611.pun_sense: an occasion (usually brief) for buying at specially reduced prices; the general activity of selling
het_611.alter_sense: travel on water propelled by wind; travel on water propelled by wind or by other means; traverse or travel on (a body of water)
het_611.human_text: Shopaholics never die , they just sale away .
het_611.human_explanation: A shopaholic is someone that is addicted to shopping. Shopping is the act of buying goods. A sale is a period of tiime when a retailer sells goods at a reduced price. "Sale away" sounds like "sail away" and "sail away" means to depart. The joke is on the word "sale away" because it sounds like "sail away" but a sale relates to the shopaholic as it is something they tend to seek and like.

het_609.pun_sense: a holding device attached to a workbench; has two jaws to hold workpiece firmly in place
het_609.alter_sense: a specific form of evildoing; moral weakness
het_609.human_text: She was only a Carpenter ' s daughter , but she knows every vise .
het_609.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "vise" is a metal tool used in carpentry but "vice" means immoral or wicked behavior.

het_608.pun_sense: provide with clothes or put clothes on; a covering designed to be worn on a person's body
het_608.alter_sense: the temporal end; the concluding time; cease to operate or cause to cease operating; the act of closing something
het_608.human_text: A men ' s wear store has opening and clothing times .
het_608.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The term "closing time" means the time a business is closed. However, "closing" sounds like "clothing" which references the fact that articles of clothing are sold at the men's wear store.

het_600.pun_sense: a division of an ocean or a large body of salt water partially enclosed by land
het_600.human_explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'seize the opportunity' which means take advantage of it and do something that you want to do, but 'seas' are used in it's place because it sounds similar to 'seize' and because sailors operate on the seas

het_597.alter_sense: the part of the leg of a human being below the ankle joint
het_597.human_text: The tightrope walker gently took a step at a time and always wore diamond - laced slippers . The spectators always would stare in awe at the tightrope walker ' s feat .
het_597.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'feat' which in this context means an achievement that requires great courage, skill, or strength, but it's also being used because it sounds exactly similar to 'feet' which is what the spectators would actually be starring at if the walker was wearing diamond-laced slippers

het_593.pun_sense: the brightest star in the sky; in Canis Major
het_593.alter_sense: concerned with work or important matters rather than play or trivialities; completely lacking in playfulness
het_593.human_text: The little green men told me it was the Dog Star . I told them they can ' t be Sirius .
het_593.human_explanation: Sirius is the name of a star located in the constellation Canis Major. Dog Star is another term used to refer to the star Sirius. Sirius sounds like "serious", and "serious" means sincere. "You can't be serious" means "you can't be sincere about what you are saying". This joke is playing on the word Sirius and its homophone serious.

het_592.pun_sense: any of the larger branches of a tree
het_592.alter_sense: an appearance by actors or performers at the end of the concert or play in order to acknowledge the applause of the audience
het_592.human_text: The cast , after the scene in the forest , took their boughs .
het_592.human_explanation: A bough is a tree branch. A bow (which sounds like bough) is when someone bends forward at the waist as a way of saying thank you to someone or to show respect to someone. In theatre, after a performance is done, the cast will come on stage at the end and take a bow. The joke is personifying a forest and using the term "boughs" which is often seen on trees to mean "bows".

het_589.pun_sense: someone who speaks by divine inspiration; someone who is an interpreter of the will of God
het_589.alter_sense: the excess of revenues over outlays in a given period of time (including depreciation and other non-cash expenses)
het_589.human_text: My family scoffed when I had a divine inspiration I ' d get rich selling my ' ' Beets Brule , ' ' but after I made my first million , they had to admit I made quite a prophet .
het_589.human_explanation: A prophet is someone who is regarded as having connection with a divine being. Prophet sounds like profit. A profit is money made when selling something. The joke is a play on the word "prophet".

het_586.pun_sense: an edible emulsion of fat globules made by churning milk or cream; for cooking and table use
het_586.alter_sense: something superior in quality or condition or effect
het_586.human_text: Why did the dairy churn ? The less said , the butter . . .
het_586.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The phrase "less said, the better" means it's better to not say much about the incident. However, "better" sounds like "butter", which is a dairy product that results when cream is churned.

het_584.alter_sense: a piece of photographic film showing an image with light and shade or colors reversed
het_584.human_text: ' ' I haven ' t had my photographs developed yet , ' ' said Tom negatively .
het_584.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. Photos that haven't developed an image yet are called the 'negatives'.  To do or say something negatively is to do it in a pessimistic or sad depressing way.

het_582.pun_sense: in a concise manner; in a few words
het_582.alter_sense: a document stating the facts and points of law of a client's case
het_582.human_text: ' ' I presented my case to the judge , ' ' Tom said briefly .
het_582.human_explanation: In the U.S. a brief is a written legal argument that is presented to a court to aid it in reaching a conclusion in a case. Briefly means fleetingly, or for a short time. The joke is playing on the word "briefly" since we can see "brief" in that word which references a legal argument presented before a judge.

het_580.pun_sense: swift timid long-eared mammal larger than a rabbit having a divided upper lip and long hind legs; young born furred and with open eyes
het_580.alter_sense: a covering for the body (or parts of it) consisting of a dense growth of threadlike structures (as on the human head); helps to prevent heat loss
het_580.human_text: The stress of having his beloved pet bunny die caused a man to go bald - - he was very upset about losing his hare .
het_580.human_explanation: Bunny is a colloquial term for young rabbits and hares. Hare sounds like hair, the loss of which is to go bald. The man is upset at the death of his pet and the resulting loss of his hair.

het_58.pun_sense: explosive device that explodes on contact; designed to destroy vehicles or ships or to kill or maim personnel
het_58.human_text: When asked to picture the perfect modern defensive weapon the Claymore springs to mine .
het_58.human_explanation: This is a play on words. To "spring to mind" means an idea has occurred to someone. However, "mind" sounds like "mine" which is a defensive weapon and one type of mine is the Claymore mine.

het_578.pun_sense: the act of waiting (remaining inactive in one place while expecting something)
het_578.alter_sense: the relative importance granted to something
het_578.human_text: Patience is a virtue that carries a lot of wait .
het_578.human_explanation: Waiting requires patience. Wait sounds like weight, but mean different things. One who can wait shows a lot of patience which is a virtue. "It carries a lot of wait" sounds like "it carries a lot of weight" which means it carries a lot of meaning.

het_574.pun_sense: strong black coffee brewed by forcing hot water under pressure through finely ground coffee beans
het_574.alter_sense: articulate; either verbally or with a cry, shout, or noise; give expression to
het_574.human_text: Why are Italians so good at making coffee ? Because they really know how to espresso themselves .
het_574.human_explanation: Espresso is a type of concentrated dark coffee that is huge in italian culinary and culture. It also sounds like express, as in to express yourself.

het_573.pun_sense: the condition of being honored (esteemed or respected or well regarded)
het_573.alter_sense: water at boiling temperature diffused in the atmosphere
het_573.human_text: On the old trains the engineer had a lot of esteem .
het_573.human_explanation: This is a pun. Esteem means confidence or respect. Some older trains use steam to function.  The engineer had a lot of esteem on the old trains because there was probably a lot of steam.

het_564.pun_sense: the basic unit of money in China
het_564.alter_sense: utter a yawn, as from lack of oxygen or when one is tired
het_564.human_text: In times like these the value of Chinese currency should make Americans pay attention . Instead , too many of us just yuan .
het_564.human_explanation: Yuan is a type of currency used in China. Yuan sounds like "yawn" in English. The joke is saying that too many people are "yawning" or are too lax because they are not paying attention to the value of the Chinese currency.

het_561.pun_sense: a strongroom or compartment (often made of steel) for safekeeping of valuables
het_561.alter_sense: the quality of being inadequate or falling short of perfection
het_561.human_text: Some bankers are generous to a vault .
het_561.human_explanation: Vault sounds like the word fault. A vault is where money or other valuables get stored. Bankers work with vaults. This is a play on the phrase "generous to a fault" with vault being used instead of the word fault. "Being generous to a fault" means that someone is generous even if it hurts them.

het_56.pun_sense: a large piece of fabric (usually canvas fabric) by means of which wind is used to propel a sailing vessel
het_56.alter_sense: a particular instance of selling; an occasion (usually brief) for buying at specially reduced prices
het_56.human_text: The boating store had its best sail ever .
het_56.human_explanation: Sail sounds like sale. A sail is a piece of material extended on a mast to collect wind. A mast is found on a boat. The "best sail ever" can be taken in the literal sense, or be understood as the "best sale ever".

het_556.pun_sense: an aircraft that has a fixed wing and is powered by propellers or jets
het_556.human_text: Don ' t expect to eat something fancy when you ' re flying because it ' s plane food .
het_556.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  'Plane' sounds the same as 'plain'.  People often refer to food served on airplanes as 'plane food' however, if food was unseasoned and tasted bland, one would call it 'plain' meaning basic, simple, or boring.

het_555.pun_sense: a state of mental disturbance and disorientation
het_555.alter_sense: an orderly grouping (of things or persons) considered as a unit; the result of arranging
het_555.human_text: The psychotic florist created many flower derangements .
het_555.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words.  The term 'flower derangements' would usually be said 'flower arrangements'.  Since the person is described as psychotic, the speaker said 'derangements' because 'deranged' is another word for psychotic or unbalanced mentally.

het_553.pun_sense: a bluish-white lustrous metallic element; brittle at ordinary temperatures but malleable when heated; used in a wide variety of alloys and in galvanizing iron; it occurs naturally as zinc sulphide in zinc blende
het_553.human_text: The cost of a galvanized hull is enough to zinc a ship .
het_553.human_explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'enough to sink a ship' which obviosuly means enough of somehing to sink a ship, but 'zinc' is used in it's place because it sounds similar to 'sink' and because it's a component used in the hull of ships

het_55.alter_sense: small piece of e.g. bread or cake
het_55.human_text: After burning a batch of cookies a baker felt very crummy .
het_55.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. Feeling 'crummy,' generally means 'feeling bad' or 'unhappy'.  Baked foods items like cookies tend to crumble and break, leaving behind crumbs, and might make an area 'crummy'.

het_545.pun_sense: kept private or confined to those intimately concerned
het_545.alter_sense: an enlisted man of the lowest rank in the Army or Marines
het_545.human_text: ' ' I ' m just an ordinary soldier , ' ' Tom admitted privately .
het_545.human_explanation: A private is a soldier of the lowest rank. Private can also mean not public, or belonging to a certain group of people only. Tom is admitting that he's an ordinary soldier, but he's only letting certain people know. The joke is playing on the word private, which can be found in the word privately.

het_543.pun_sense: transmitting light; able to be seen through with clarity
het_543.alter_sense: a father or mother; one who begets or one who gives birth to or nurtures and raises a child; a relative who plays the role of guardian
het_543.human_text: Did you hear about the father that was difficult to see ? He was transparent .
het_543.human_explanation: Transparent means clear or able to see through, and it contains the word parent in it as in a father or mother. This pun is referncing a father who is hard to see, as in invisibile, which means transparent.

het_542.pun_sense: slowly as if burdened by much weight
het_542.alter_sense: of comparatively great physical weight or density
het_542.human_text: ' ' I ' ve gained thirty pounds , ' ' said Tom heavily .
het_542.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  To gain pounds would make someone heavy.  To say something heavily means to say it to a great degree; in large amounts, or with great force.

het_540.alter_sense: a heavy ductile magnetic metallic element; is silver-white in pure form but readily rusts; used in construction and tools and armament; plays a role in the transport of oxygen by the blood
het_540.human_text: ' ' It ' s my personal magnetism , ' ' said Tom ironically .
het_540.human_explanation: I think the joke is that 'ironically' sounds somewhat like 'ionically'.  'Ironically' is used to denote a paradoxical, unexpected, or coincidental situation. An ion is an atom or molecule with a net electric charge due to the loss or gain of one or more electrons. Having a charge means something would be magnetized toward something else with an opposite charge.

het_54.pun_sense: viscera and trimmings of a butchered animal often considered inedible by humans
het_54.alter_sense: exceptionally bad or displeasing; causing fear or dread or terror; offensive or even (of persons) malicious; ; ; ; ; ; - Ezra Pound
het_54.human_text: When asked by a Health Department official to describe the mess he saw on the slaughterhouse floor , the USDA inspector replied , ' ' It was just offal . ' '
het_54.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'awful' which means very bad or unpleasant, but 'offal' is used in it's place because it sounds similar and because 'offal' is the entrails and internal organs of an animal used as food, which is something you'd find at a slaughterhouse

het_538.alter_sense: lacking in substance or character; devoid of significance or force
het_538.human_text: I feel empty inside , Tom hollered .
het_538.human_explanation: This joke doesn't make sense because 'hollered' does not sound enough like 'hollow', and it creats a bizarre mental image.

het_535.pun_sense: wingless usually flattened bloodsucking insect parasitic on warm-blooded animals
het_535.alter_sense: a statement that deviates from or perverts the truth
het_535.human_text: Don ' t believe what you hear about fleas and ticks - - it ' s all lice .
het_535.human_explanation: A flea is a type of insect that feeds on the blood of mammals. A tick is a type of parasitic bug that also feeds on blood. Lice is the plural of louse, a type of parasitic insect that feed on blood. Lice kind of sounds like "lies". The word "lice" was used to replace "lies" as a joke because the joke is talking about insects that feed on blood. This joke is playing on the word lice.

het_534.pun_sense: plaything consisting of a sloping chute down which children can slide
het_534.alter_sense: a place within a region identified relative to a center or reference location
het_534.human_text: The chicken crossed the playground to get to the other slide .
het_534.human_explanation: "The chicken crossed the road to get to the other side" is a common quote. The word "side" sounds close to "slide". The writer put "slide" in to sound close to "side" and to relate it to the playground the chicken crossed. Playgrounds have lots of slides.

het_528.alter_sense: the terminal section of the alimentary canal; from the sigmoid flexure to the anus
het_528.human_text: The proctologist reassured the patient that his condition could be rectified .
het_528.human_explanation: This is a pun using the word "rectified". The proctologist is telling the patient that his condition could be "rectified" which means fixed. "Rectified" has the sound "rect" in it, which sounds like "rectum". A proctologist specializes in issues with the rectum.

het_527.pun_sense: an architectural ornament consisting of a horizontal sculptured band between the architrave and the cornice
het_527.alter_sense: weather cold enough to cause freezing
het_527.human_text: As they looked at the recreation of the Greek temple on Rodeo Drive while a freak ice storm was occurring , Emily and Henry were astonished by the very unusual frieze .
het_527.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  The word 'freeze' sounds the same as 'frieze'.  A frieze is a broad horizontal band of sculpted or painted decoration, especially on a wall near the ceiling, and can typically be found in Greek architecture.  The other 'freeze' is referring to the cold temperature or precipitation from the ice storm.

het_522.alter_sense: the psychological feature that arouses an organism to action toward a desired goal; the reason for the action; that which gives purpose and direction to behavior; a condition requiring relief
het_522.human_text: Bakers have a great knead to make bread .
het_522.human_explanation: The joke is a pun on the word knead.  Kneading is the act of pressing on the dough to get it ready for baking.  Knead sounds like 'need', so in the phrase, "Bakers have a great knead," it sounds like they have a great desire to do something.

het_520.pun_sense: the collection and study of postage stamps
het_520.human_text: What did the nice girl say when her date invited her home to see his stamp collection ? ' Philately will get you nowhere ' .
het_520.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "philately" means the collection and study of postage but sounds like "flattery" meaning excessive and insincere praise.

het_513.pun_sense: mild yellow Dutch cheese made in balls encased in a red covering
het_513.alter_sense: (Old Testament) in Judeo-Christian mythology; the first man and the husband of Eve and the progenitor of the human race
het_513.human_text: To emphasize that someone is a stranger : ' ' As we used to say in the cheese industry , I don ' t know him from Edam . ' '
het_513.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The phrase "don't know him from Adam" is used when someone doesn't know a person. However, "Adam" sounds like "edam" which is a type of cheese.
human_keywords: don' t know him from Edam

het_510.pun_sense: a person who is entitled by law or by the terms of a will to inherit the estate of another
het_510.alter_sense: a covering for the body (or parts of it) consisting of a dense growth of threadlike structures (as on the human head); helps to prevent heat loss
het_510.human_text: The prodigal son was having a bad heir day .
het_510.human_explanation: This is a pun on "heir". The prodigal son was having a bad hair day. Hair sounds like heir. An heir is a person who has the legal right to the rank or property of someone who has died. The prodigal son is from a bible story about a son who inherits his father's fortune and wastes it all. Thus, he was a "bad heir".

het_51.pun_sense: a characteristic (habitual or relatively temporary) state of feeling
het_51.alter_sense: the sound made by a cow or bull; make a low noise, characteristic of bovines
het_51.human_text: Cows make noise only when they ' re in the mood .
het_51.human_explanation: The sound a cow makes is "moo". The word "moo" can be found in "mood". When someone or something is "in the mood" it means they feel like doing something. This joke is playing on the word "mood" because it has "moo" in it which references the sound a cow makes.

het_509.human_text: I ' ve caught Moby Dick ! Tom wailed .
het_509.human_explanation: Wailed is a sound someone makes when in a state of distress. Wailed sounds like "whaled". Moby Dick is the name of a whale found in the book Moby Dick.

het_506.pun_sense: in a secretive manner; with a preference for secrecy
het_506.alter_sense: generate and separate from cells or bodily fluids
het_506.human_text: ' ' I won ' t tell you anything about my salivary glands , ' ' said Tom secretively .
het_506.human_explanation: Salivary glands secrete saliva. Secrete means to produce. Secretively means to go about quietly and hidden from others. Secretively is a play on the word secrete and secret.

het_505.alter_sense: increase; raise the level or amount of something; cause to be heard or known; express or utter
het_505.human_text: Sellers of dried grapes are always raisin awareness .
het_505.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. Dried grapes are raisins. 'Raisin' sounds like 'raising' and in the context 'raising awareness' it sounds like they are trying to spread information.

het_504.alter_sense: (Old Testament) Adam's wife in Judeo-Christian mythology: the first woman and mother of the human race; God created Eve from Adam's rib and placed Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden
het_504.human_text: I ' ll tempt Adam tonight , she said evilly .
het_504.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "evilly" means having evil, immoral or wicked intent. However "Eve" references the Biblical character who forced Adam to eat from the Tree of Life in the Old Testament.

het_503.pun_sense: a republic consisting of 26 of 32 counties comprising the island of Ireland; achieved independence from the United Kingdom in 1921
het_503.alter_sense: a mixture of gases (especially oxygen) required for breathing; the stuff that the wind consists of
het_503.human_text: People have a happy time vacationing in Ireland because they are walking on Eire .
het_503.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The phrase "walking on air" means feeling very happy but "air" sounds like "Eire" which is Irish for Ireland. So here "walking on Eire" means walking in the country of Ireland.

het_501.alter_sense: New Zealand mountaineer who in 1953 first attained the summit of Mount Everest with his Sherpa guide Tenzing Norgay (born in 1919)
het_501.human_text: ' ' I was the first to climb Mount Everest , ' ' said Tom hilariously .
het_501.human_explanation: "Hilariously" has the sound "hil" in it, which sounds like "hill". Mount Everest is a mountain and a mountain are kind of like a hill, only much larger.

het_5.pun_sense: large African antelope having a head with horns like an ox and a long tufted tail
het_5.alter_sense: informal information of any kind that is not previously known to someone
het_5.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "gnus" Gnus are wildebeests. "gnus" sounds like "news". The evil wildebeests are bad news because they are bad gnus.

het_498.pun_sense: passageway between seating areas as in an auditorium or passenger vehicle or between areas of shelves of goods as in stores
het_498.human_text: Although he perfected his comic routines on the mainland , his best audiences were in the aisles .
het_498.human_explanation: Ailes' here is a pun on 'Isles': refers to audience members that didn't live on the mainland. Most likely, his biggest fans preferred to watch him from the aisles instead of from seats.

het_497.pun_sense: bone extending from the shoulder to the elbow
het_497.alter_sense: full of or characterized by humor
het_497.human_text: Greys Anatomy has many humerus remarks .
het_497.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  'Humerus' is the name of a bone in the body, and sounds like the word 'humorous' which means jokingly, funny, or comical.  Grey's Anatomy is a show about doctors and nurses in a hospital, so the word 'humorous' was replaced with 'humerus' the bone.

het_493.pun_sense: a barrier constructed to contain the flow of water or to keep out the sea
het_493.human_text: I saw a beaver movie last night , it was the best dam movie I ' ve ever seen .
het_493.human_explanation: Beavers make dams. A dam is a structure that beavers build to protect themselves from predators that could hurt them. A dam can also refer to a manmade structure used to make artificial lakes. The word "dam" is insersted after "best" to express enthusiasm and joy over something.

het_489.pun_sense: an army unit usually consisting of two or more divisions and their support
het_489.alter_sense: the choicest or most essential or most vital part of some idea or experience
het_489.human_text: She was only a Colonel ' s Daughter , but she was great to the navy and rotten to the corps .
het_489.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  The phrase 'rotten to corps' sounds like 'rotten to the core' which would mean somebody has a 'cool', 'bad guy' attitude or behavior. The word 'corps' means a main subdivision of an armed force in the field, consisting of two or more divisions.

het_488.human_text: John Deere has just released its most powerful tractor yet . It is the torque of the town .
het_488.human_explanation: "It is the torque of the town" sounds like "It is the talk of the town" meaning lots of people are talking about it. Torque is a measure of how much force it takes to cause an object to rotate. The more torque an engine produces, the greater its ability to perform work. The joke is referencing John Deere's most powerful tractor yet and replaced "talk" with "torque".

het_485.pun_sense: connected with or belonging to or used in a navy
het_485.alter_sense: a scar where the umbilical cord was attached
het_485.human_text: The sailor called his girlfriend ' s belly ring a naval destroyer .
het_485.human_explanation: A "naval destroyer" is a warship. "Naval" is a homophone of "navel". The navel is the place on a person's belly where the umbilical cord detached after birth. When the belly button gets pierced, the skin experiences trauma, maybe even gets a bit destroyed, and has to heal around the piercing. The sailor's girlfriend has a belly ring. This is where "navel destroyer" makes sense. This joke is playing on the term "naval destroyer" because it sounds like "navel destroyer".

het_481.pun_sense: a male member of a royal family other than the sovereign (especially the son of a sovereign)
het_481.alter_sense: a printed picture produced from a photographic negative
het_481.human_text: On my tour of the U . K . , Charles invited me to cook at Buckingham Palace , and naturally , I took photos so I could show everyone the prince .
het_481.human_explanation: A prince is a male member of a royal family. Another word for photos is prints. Prints sounds like prince although they mean two different things. "Show everyone the prince" sounds like "show everyone the prints" or photos.

het_480.pun_sense: the sound made by corvine birds
het_480.human_text: A crow in a telephone booth had no money so he had to make a collect caw .
het_480.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  'Caw' is the noise a crow makes, and the word sounds like 'call'.  A collect call is when one makes a phone call reversing the charges.

het_473.alter_sense: any of numerous plants of the genus Gladiolus native chiefly to tropical and South Africa having sword-shaped leaves and one-sided spikes of brightly colored funnel-shaped flowers; widely cultivated
het_473.human_text: Look at those tall flowers , said Tom gladly .
het_473.human_explanation: I think gladly has to do something with flowers

het_471.pun_sense: a particular point in the time of a cycle; measured from some arbitrary zero and expressed as an angle; adjust so as to be in a synchronized condition
het_471.human_text: I got a nasty electric shock the other day , but I wasn ' t phased .
het_471.human_explanation: Electrick shocks vary by degrees, or phases. 'Phased' here is also used a pun on 'fazed', or bothered.

het_469.pun_sense: not injurious to physical or mental health
het_469.alter_sense: perform vaccinations or produce immunity in by inoculation
het_469.human_text: Some resist having the ' flu jab but it ' s quite innocuous .
het_469.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words. 'Innocuous' means 'not harmful or offensive.' However the word sounds similar to 'innoculant' which means 'vaccination.'

het_468.pun_sense: a short nail with a sharp point and a large head
het_468.alter_sense: charge against a citizen's person or property or activity for the support of government
het_468.human_text: My sofa was repaired , but I was surprised to find an item on the bill for upholstery tacks .
het_468.human_explanation: This is a play on words. An "upholstery tack" is a sharp pin used to affix upholstery material to furniture like sofas. However, "tacks" sounds like "tax" meaning an extra fee placed on a bill. Here, an "upholstery tacks" refers both to tacks placed on the sofa and an extra charge for the upholstery.

het_466.pun_sense: a severe recurring vascular headache; occurs more frequently in women than men
het_466.human_text: A bird with a headache might just migrane south .
het_466.human_explanation: Migrane is a type of painful headache. Migrane sounds like migrate, which is the act of birds flying to warmer areas during cold weather.  The bird has a headache, so it migranes south.

het_461.pun_sense: ancient Greece; a country of city-states (especially Athens and Sparta) that reached its peak in the fifth century BCE; a republic in southeastern Europe on the southern part of the Balkan peninsula; known for grapes and olives and olive oil
het_461.alter_sense: a thick fatty oil (especially one used to lubricate machinery)
het_461.human_text: Did you know that donuts were first made in Greece ?
het_461.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'Greece', implying that donuts were created in the country of Greece, but it's also being used because it sounds similar to grease, the oil, which donuts were actually first made in

het_460.pun_sense: a member of an irregular armed force that fights a stronger force by sabotage and harassment
het_460.alter_sense: largest anthropoid ape; terrestrial and vegetarian; of forests of central west Africa
het_460.human_text: Guerrilla warfare is more than just throwing a banana .
het_460.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'guerrilla warfare' which is "type of warfare fought by irregulars in fast-moving, small-scale actions against orthodox military". 'Banana' is mentioned here because it's associsted with gorillas which sounds similar to 'guerrilla'

het_46.pun_sense: any cold-blooded vertebrate of the class Reptilia including tortoises, turtles, snakes, lizards, alligators, crocodiles, and extinct forms
het_46.alter_sense: a flat thin rectangular slab (as of fired clay or rubber or linoleum) used to cover surfaces
het_46.human_text: What kind of flooring do alligator hunters use ? Reptiles !
het_46.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'reptiles' which are vertebrate animals of a class that includes snakes, lizards, crocodiles, turtles, tortoises, and alligators. 'Reptiles' is also being used because it includes the word 'tiles' which is a type of flooring

het_459.pun_sense: with patience; in a patient manner
het_459.alter_sense: a person who requires medical care
het_459.human_text: ' ' I ' m waiting to see the doctor , ' ' said Tom patiently .
het_459.human_explanation: This is a pun on "patiently". Patiently has the word "patient" in it. A patient is the person a doctor takes care of. Tom is waiting to see the doctor, so he is a patient who is waiting patiently.

het_458.pun_sense: a sign of something about to happen
het_458.alter_sense: orienting or directing homeward or to a destination
het_458.human_text: My pet bird can predict the future . He is an omen pigeon .
het_458.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The term "homing pigeon" means a type of pigeon that can find its way home from extremely long distances but "homing" sounds like "omen" meaning an event of prophetic significance or something which can predict the future..

het_457.pun_sense: a group of many things in the air or on the ground
het_457.human_text: A bee keeper will sell you honey with swarm wishes .
het_457.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words. 'Swarm wishes' is used instead of 'warm wishes'.  Bees can fly around in large groups called swarms.  'Warm wishes' is generally wishing somebody a good day or similar nice things people say.

het_45.pun_sense: a period marked by distinctive character or reckoned from a fixed point or event
het_45.alter_sense: the sense organ for hearing and equilibrium
het_45.human_text: Fashion is something that goes in one era and out the other .
het_45.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words.  An 'era' is a long and distinct period of history with a particular feature or characteristic. 'Era' sounds like 'ear' which would have made the phrase 'in one ear, out the other', and generally means ignored.  In terms of fashion, an era of a fashion trend would mean it is currently 'in' or popular for one style, but once the era ends that style would be 'out' or unpopular in comparison to other modern styles.

het_444.pun_sense: United States film maker who pioneered animated cartoons and created such characters as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck; founded Disneyland (1901-1966)
het_444.alter_sense: having or causing a whirling sensation; liable to falling
het_444.human_text: Mickey Mouse gives some people Disney spells .

het_435.pun_sense: the posterior part of the body of a vertebrate especially when elongated and extending beyond the trunk or main part of the body
het_435.alter_sense: a message that tells the particulars of an act or occurrence or course of events; presented in writing or drama or cinema or as a radio or television program
het_435.human_text: Lizards have a very strong heartbeat which can be faintly heard anywhere on their body , said Mr . Johnson , beginning a story . ' ' Come listen to this tail . ' '
het_435.human_explanation: The joke is in the use of the word tail. A tale is another word for a story, but since they are talking about lizards, it is literally about the tail body part of a lizard. 'Come listen to this tail' sounds like the speaker is beginning to tell a long story, but they literally mean that you can hear the heartbeat of the lizard through its tail.

het_434.pun_sense: following the third position; number four in a countable series; coming next after the third and just before the fifth in position or time or degree or magnitude
het_434.alter_sense: a powerful effect or influence; one possessing or exercising power or influence or authority
