het_1571.pun_sense: compound leaf of a fern or palm or cycad
het_1571.alter_sense: inclined to help or support; not antagonistic or hostile
het_1571.human_text: When Jesus entered Jerusalem , people waved palm branches because they were being frondly .
het_1571.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "friendly" means nice or pleasant but "frond" (as in frondly) is the leaflike part of palm branches that the people in Jerusalem were waving.

het_157.human_explanation: This joke is replacing the word fried in kentuckey fried chicken (KFC) with freud, as in sigmund freud, a famous psychologist.

het_1569.alter_sense: pass from physical life and lose all bodily attributes and functions necessary to sustain life
het_1569.human_text: A cloth maker ' s daughter told him she was too young to dye .
het_1569.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words.  The phrase said is typically 'I'm too young to die' where 'die' means death, the end of life.  'Dye' which sounds identical was used instead, and means staining colors into cloth.

het_1561.alter_sense: complete and without restriction or qualification; sometimes used informally as intensifiers
het_1561.human_text: I like wool gathering for the shear joy of it .
het_1561.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. 'Shear' is to cut or shave the wool off of a sheep with tools called 'shears'.  'Shear' sounds like 'sheer' which means 'utter' or 'pure'.  The phrase said is typically 'sheer joy'.

het_156.pun_sense: a firearm that is held and fired with one hand
het_156.alter_sense: the female ovule-bearing part of a flower composed of ovary and style and stigma
het_156.human_text: The pistol of a flower is its only protections against insects .
het_156.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. The 'pisitl' is the female organs of a flower, comprising the stigma, style, and ovary. 'Pisitl' sounds similar to 'pistol' which is a gun.

het_1557.pun_sense: pancake batter baked in a waffle iron
het_1557.alter_sense: extreme in degree or extent or amount or impact
het_1557.human_text: Jim : ' Did you hear about the guy who ate twenty pancakes for breakfast ? ' Joe : ' How waffle . '
het_1557.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words.  Saying 'how waffle' sounds similar to saying 'how awful'.  A waffle is a similar breakfast item to a pancake.

het_1549.alter_sense: a swinging or sliding barrier that will close the entrance to a room or building or vehicle
het_1549.human_text: They are not answering - we ' d better try the knocker , said Tom adoringly .
het_1549.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  The word 'adoringly' sounds like it has the words 'a door' in it when spoken out loud.  The speaker is knocking on a door.  To do or say something 'adoringly' means to do it with admiration or love.

het_1546.pun_sense: one of the Muslim people of north Africa; of mixed Arab and Berber descent; converted to Islam in the 8th century; conqueror of Spain in the 8th century
het_1546.alter_sense: (comparative of `much' used with mass nouns) a quantifier meaning greater in size or amount or extent or degree; comparative of much; to a greater degree or extent
het_1546.human_text: The tired playgoers decided to bypass the new production of ' ' Othello ' ' despite the good reviews ; having just returned from a long trip , they didn ' t feel like seeing any moor of Venice .
het_1546.human_explanation: When you moor a boat, you attach a boat somewhere. Venice is a city in Italy with a lot of water channels that boats can travel on. "Moor" sounds like the word "more". The people in this joke did not want to see any "more of Venice". This joke is playing on the word "moor" because it relates to attaching your boat somewhere, and it's a homophone of more.

het_1531.pun_sense: optical device having a triangular shape and made of glass or quartz; used to deviate a beam or invert an image
het_1531.alter_sense: a correctional institution where persons are confined while on trial or for punishment
het_1531.human_text: The optical scientist who stole his colleague ' s bifocals was sentenced to three years in a state prism .
het_1531.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. Optical scientists experiment with the way light reflects and is percieved by the eye.  A prism is an object that reflects light or splits it into the spectrum of the rainbow.  'Prism' sounds like 'prison'.

het_153.pun_sense: a slice of meat cut from the fleshy part of an animal or large fish
het_153.alter_sense: a strong wooden or metal post with a point at one end so it can be driven into the ground
het_153.human_text: Legends tell us that a weakness of the carnivorous vampire is a steak .
het_153.human_explanation: Steak and stake are homophones. A steak if a piece of meat. A stake is a pointed piece of wood. In folklore, driving a stake through the heart of a vampire was the only want to kill it. A carnivore, or someone carnivorous, is someone that eats meat. The joke is playing on the word "steak" because it sounds like "stake" and both apply to this joke and make sense.

het_1528.pun_sense: strong espresso coffee with a topping of frothed steamed milk
het_1528.alter_sense: after the expected or usual time; delayed
het_1528.human_text: If you spend too much time in the coffee shop you ' ll be latte for work .
het_1528.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  A 'latte' is a type of coffee drink one could get at a coffee shop.  The word 'latte' is similar to 'late', so in the phrase 'late for work' it is replaced with 'latte'.

het_1527.alter_sense: come to a halt, stop moving
het_1527.human_text: ' ' I can ' t march any more ! ' ' the soldier called haltingly .
het_1527.human_explanation: The joke is in the use of the word haltingly. The soldier can't march anymore, so he wants to halt--stop marching.  Speaking haltingly means to speak nervously, stopping often while speaking.

het_1526.pun_sense: a rich soil consisting of a mixture of sand and clay and decaying organic materials
het_1526.human_text: That soil scientist always travels by himself . He ' s a loam ranger .
het_1526.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  Loam is a type of soil, and sounds like the word 'lone'.  The phrase would be 'lone ranger' which generally means that person is does things on their own.

het_1525.pun_sense: carve, cut, or etch into a material or surface; carve or cut a design or letters into
het_1525.alter_sense: a place for the burial of a corpse (especially beneath the ground and marked by a tombstone)
het_1525.human_explanation: has to know what Epitaphs means

het_1519.alter_sense: any period of seven consecutive days
het_1519.human_text: Seven days without a pun makes one weak .
het_1519.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'one weak' which is implying that living seven days without pun jokes would make someone weak, but it's also being used because 'one week' sounds similar and it's referrignto the fact that seven days equal one week

het_1518.pun_sense: any property detected by the olfactory system
het_1518.human_text: Getting into the skunk selling business might make a lot of scents .
het_1518.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. 'Scents' means smells, like how skunks have strong smells, but the word sounds just like 'cents' meaning coins, or money, and it also sounds like 'sense' which is a rational idea that has understandable reasoning.

het_1515.pun_sense: a configuration of stars as seen from the earth
het_1515.alter_sense: the comfort you feel when consoled in times of disappointment
het_1515.human_text: The astronomer ' s research project didn ' t win him the coveted Galaxy Award , but he did receive a constellation prize .
het_1515.human_explanation: A consolation prize is a prize given to someone who fails to win, and is a gesture of good efforts - and it sounds like the word constellation, which refers to systems of galaxies and astronomical bodies. An astronomer is someone who studies space, so it's a pun on the topic of astronomy.

het_1508.pun_sense: with bitterness; in a resentful manner; indicating something hard to accept
het_1508.alter_sense: causing a sharp and acrid taste experience
het_1508.human_text: ' We ' ve run out of lemons ' , she said bitterly .
het_1508.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. Lemons are sour or bitter tasting fruit. To say something 'bitterly' is to say it in an angry, hurt, or resentful way.

het_1506.alter_sense: become weaker; become feeble; lose freshness, vigor, or vitality
het_1506.human_text: OLD BATHING BEAUTIES never die , they just wade away .
het_1506.human_explanation: Pun on "old ____ never die, they just fade away", with "wade" replacing "fade". Bathing beauties were/are a common class of model often photographed in swimwear, though the term itself is antiquated. If they are in water, they could *wade* through it, hence the pun.

het_1505.pun_sense: sweet potato with deep orange flesh that remains moist when baked
het_1505.alter_sense: have the quality of being; (copula, used with an adjective or a predicate noun)
het_1505.human_explanation: "I yam impressed" sounds like "I am impressed". Yam is a type of sweet potato. The joke is running together the words "I am" to make it sound like "yam".

het_1504.pun_sense: fresh leaves (or leaves preserved in vinegar) used as seasoning
het_1504.alter_sense: model of excellence or perfection of a kind; one having no equal; an ideal instance; a perfect embodiment of a concept
het_1504.human_text: Did you hear about the herb who was an all round great guy , did loads of charity work and was always there to help ? He was a Tarragon Of Virtue .
het_1504.human_explanation: A virtue is an act of goodness. Tarragon of Virtue is a type of herb. The writer is personifying the herb, and since it has the word "virtue" in it, making it sound like a integrous being.

het_1503.pun_sense: the educator who has executive authority for a school
het_1503.human_text: OLD SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENTS  never die , they just lose their principals .
het_1503.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "principals". The word "principles" has been replaced by the identical-sounding word "principals" because school "principals" are a superintendent's employees and this joke is about superintendents.

het_1499.pun_sense: (medicine) bleached cotton cloth of plain weave used for bandages and dressings
het_1499.alter_sense: a justification for something existing or happening
het_1499.human_text: A surgery nurse was demoted for being absent without gauze .
het_1499.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The phrase "absent without cause" means abandoning work without justification. However, "cause" sound like "gauze", which is a fabric commonly used by nurses to provide medical treatment.

het_1495.alter_sense: a barrier constructed to contain the flow of water or to keep out the sea
het_1495.human_text: Some people , asked what they thought had caused the recent flooding in our valley , pointed to a concrete wall in the distance and said it was this damn thing .
het_1495.human_explanation: Pun. The concrete wall in the distance that caused the flooding is a dam. The people say 'it was this damn thing' as if they are upset about it enough to say 'damn' but  it's literally 'this dam, thing'.

het_1494.alter_sense: a medical institution where sick or injured people are given medical or surgical care; a health facility where patients receive treatment
het_1494.human_text: Have a ride in my new ambulance , said Tom hospitably .
het_1494.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. To say or do something 'hospitably' is to be receiving or treating guests or strangers warmly and generously.  The word 'hospitably' is similar to 'hospital' which is a medical facility that an ambulence would be used to transfer an injured or sick person to.

het_1492.pun_sense: the immaterial part of a person; the actuating cause of an individual life
het_1492.alter_sense: the underside of footwear or a golf club
het_1492.human_text: Need soul repair ? Walk right in .
het_1492.human_explanation: This is a joke that only works in writing. It surprises the reader by using the spiritual spelling of 'soul', before implying that it meant the 'sole' of a shoe, hence 'walk right in'. It could, however, still refer to a place of worship.

het_1491.alter_sense: affording unobstructed entrance and exit; not shut or closed
het_1491.human_text: ' ' The door ' s ajar , ' ' said Tom openly .
het_1491.human_explanation: Ajar means slightly open. Tom said the door was ajar, openly. Openly means to be direct and honest. We see the word "open" in openly, and "open" describes the door. This joke is playing on the word "openly".

het_1490.pun_sense: brine-cured salmon that is lightly smoked
het_1490.alter_sense: a fastener fitted to a door or drawer to keep it firmly closed
het_1490.human_text: To keep someone from stealing your shipments of smoked salmon , secure them with lox .
het_1490.human_explanation: Lox is brined salmon, a type of fish. Lox is the homophone of locks. Locks are metal mechanisms used to keep a door, or lid fastened shut. "Secure them with lox" sounds like "secure them with locks" or secure the fish with locks so no one can steal them. The joke is on the word "lox" and its homophone "locks".

het_1486.pun_sense: a member of an irregular armed force that fights a stronger force by sabotage and harassment
het_1486.alter_sense: largest anthropoid ape; terrestrial and vegetarian; of forests of central west Africa
het_1486.human_text: Scrambling for cover amid the chaos caused by the rebel forces ' attack and the ' ' coincidental ' ' breakout of the zoo animals , I stumbled into the face of a hostile guerrilla !
het_1486.human_explanation: Guerrilla warfare refers to warfare that is irregular and informal. Guerrilla sounds like gorilla, and a gorilla is an animal that can be found at zoos. This is a play on the word guerrilla.

het_1484.pun_sense: the passionate and demonstrative activity of expressing grief
het_1484.alter_sense: the time period between dawn and noon
het_1484.human_text: Those who drink too much at night have to worry about the mourning after .
het_1484.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. 'Mourning' means to feel or show deep sorrow or regret for (someone or their death), typically by following conventions such as the wearing of black clothes. Mourning sounds identical to 'morning' which means the time of day after sunrise and before noon. I suppose a heavy drinker would regret drinking so much when they are hung over the next morning.

het_1475.pun_sense: enthusiastic greeting; greet enthusiastically or joyfully
het_1475.human_text: When Caesar entered the Senate all hail broke loose .
het_1475.human_explanation: This is an historical reference to the Roman senators stabbing Caesar. It was a chaotic event where "all hell (hail) broke loose" - a clever play on words because the senators would greet him with "Hail Caesar!". This joke relies on outside historical knowledge, but it's very clever.

het_1474.pun_sense: superior Bordeaux type of red wine
het_1474.alter_sense: a storage compartment for clothes and valuables; usually it has a lock; a piece of furniture resembling a cupboard with doors and shelves and drawers; for storage or display
het_1474.human_text: You should lock up your wine in a cabernet .
het_1474.human_explanation: Cabernet is a type of wine. If you incorrectly pronounce cabernet, as in you pronounce the "t" instead of make it silent, the word kind of sounds like "cabinet". A cabinet is a cupboard with shelves that you can lock. This joke is playing on the word Cabernet because it is a name of a wine and kind of sounds like cabinet if mispronounced.

het_1473.pun_sense: the act of stealing valuable things from a place; the act of stealing valuable things from a place
het_1473.alter_sense: a dose of medicine in the form of a small pellet
het_1473.human_text: Looting a drugstore is called Pillaging .
het_1473.human_explanation: This is a pun. Drugstores are commonly a place to pick up medicine, whether prescribed or available on the shelf. This commonly comes in the form of pills. Pillaging is a form of theft or looting. The pun relies on the overlap between "pill" and "pillaging".

het_1468.alter_sense: one of the two male reproductive glands that produce spermatozoa and secrete androgens
het_1468.human_text: When I suffered a groin injury I became quite testy .
het_1468.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. To become 'testy' is to be irritable or angered easily.  'Testy' sounds similar to 'testicles' which are the male genitalia found in the groin area.

het_1466.pun_sense: any of various burrowing animals of the family Leporidae having long ears and short tails; some domesticated and raised for pets or food
het_1466.alter_sense: characterized by speed; moving with or capable of moving with high speed
het_1466.human_text: How do bunnies that don ' t have a car commute to work ? The Rabbit Transit .
het_1466.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The phrase "rabbit transit" refers to how rabbits get themselves places. But "rabbit transit" sounds like "rapid transit", which is a type of public transportation in urban areas.

het_1461.pun_sense: in a level and regular way
het_1461.alter_sense: (Old Testament) Adam's wife in Judeo-Christian mythology: the first woman and mother of the human race; God created Eve from Adam's rib and placed Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden
het_1461.human_text: I wouldn ' t marry you if you were the only woman on earth , said Tom evenly .
het_1461.human_explanation: Evenly is an adverb that means calmly. I think this joke is poking at an "Eve" reference. Eve was the first woman to exist on Earth, and for awhile was the only woman to exist on Earth according to the Bible in the book of Genesis. "Eve" can be found in "evenly".

het_1457.pun_sense: the ripened reproductive body of a seed plant
het_1457.alter_sense: killing someone by gunfire; the act of firing a projectile
het_1457.human_text: A band of teenagers cruised past my neighbor ' s house and pelted it with rotten tomatoes . Police described it as a drive - by fruiting .
het_1457.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The term "drive-by shooting" is a type of assault where perpetrators fire weapons from a motor vehicle. However, "shooting" sounds like "fruiting" which in this context involves teenagers shooting fruit and a building instead of guns.

het_1456.pun_sense: a thin porridge (usually oatmeal or cornmeal)
het_1456.alter_sense: (of persons or their actions) able or disposed to inflict pain or suffering
het_1456.human_text: The soup was so bad it was gruel and unusual punishment .
het_1456.human_explanation: "Gruel and unusual punishment" sounds like "cruel and unusual punishment" which is a phrase in common law that describes a punishment considered unacceptable due to the pain of the punishment being excessive and not matching the crime committed. Gruel is a type of food consisting of oats, wheat, or rye that has a lot of liquid. Gruel is a lot like soup because they both have a high water content. This joke is playing on "gruel and unusual punishment" because it sounds like "cruel and unusual punishment".

het_1454.pun_sense: cut or eliminate; wipe out digitally or magnetically recorded information; remove or make invisible
het_1454.alter_sense: a feeling of extreme pleasure or satisfaction
het_1454.human_text: The editor received his award with sheer delete .
het_1454.human_explanation: "Sheer delete" sounds like "sheer delight". An editor is someone that is responsible for checking facts, spelling, grammar, and punctuation, and sometimes that involves deleting what is present. The editor was happy about his award, just delete was used instead of delight.

het_1450.pun_sense: symptom consisting of a localized collection of pus surrounded by inflamed tissue
het_1450.alter_sense: be preoccupied with something; having or showing excessive or compulsive concern with something
het_1450.human_text: I was fixated on the pain in my bad tooth . I was abscessed by it .
het_1450.human_explanation: An abscess can refer to a pocket of pus that forms around the root of an infected tooth. "Abscessed by it" sounds like "obsessed by it" which means to be continuously preoccupied with something. The joke is referring to someone who keeps thinking about the pain in their tooth, and the word "abscess" was chosen as it closely matches the sound of the word "obsess" and can relate to why their tooth hurts.

het_145.alter_sense: (used in the plural) a mechanical device that blows a strong current of air; used to make a fire burn more fiercely or to sound a musical instrument
het_145.human_text: ' ' I have to keep this fire alight , ' ' Tom bellowed .
het_145.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  'Bellows' are a tool that is used to blow air into a flame to keep it lit with oxygen.  To 'bellow' in speech is to yell or holler.

het_1449.pun_sense: right-eyed flatfish; many are valued as food; most common in warm seas especially European
het_1449.alter_sense: the immaterial part of a person; the actuating cause of an individual life
het_1449.human_text: He owned a fish farm until he poured out his sole .
het_1449.human_explanation: A sole is a type of fish, and sounds like soul as in pouring your soul out.

het_1447.pun_sense: follow at the heels of a person
het_1447.human_text: The veterinarian had a great deal of trouble getting his dog to heel .
het_1447.human_explanation: Pun on "heal" and "heel", which sound the same. Veterinarians medically treat animals, or heal them, and "heel" is a common command to train dogs to obey.

het_1444.pun_sense: winder consisting of a revolving spool with a handle; attached to a fishing rod
het_1444.alter_sense: used as intensifiers; `real' is sometimes used informally for `really'; `rattling' is informal
het_1444.human_text: OLD FISHERMEN never die , they just get reel tired .
het_1444.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'real tired' which simply means to be very tired, but 'reel' is used in it's place because it sounds exactly similar and because it is also a cylinder on which film, wire, thread, or other flexible materials can be wound, like that of a fishing rod

het_1442.alter_sense: the green acidic fruit of any of various lime trees
het_1442.human_text: When it comes to drinks , citrus fruit juices are always in the limelight .
het_1442.human_explanation: If something's 'in the limelight', it hogs all the attention away from others in its category. It's also a play on limes - a kind of citrus fruit.

het_1441.pun_sense: the characteristic sounds made by a horse
het_1441.human_text: She was only a Horseman ' s daughter , but she didn ' t know how to say neigh .
het_1441.human_explanation: neigh is a characteristic high-pitched sound uttered by a horse.

het_1436.alter_sense: an area of skin that is thick or hard from continual pressure or friction (as the sole of the foot)
het_1436.human_text: ' ' Rowing hurts my hands , ' ' said Tom callously .
het_1436.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'callously' which means in a way that shows an insensitive and cruel disregard for others; unfeelingly, but it's also used because the alternate spelling of 'callus' means a thickened and hardened part of the skin or soft tissue, especially in an area that has been subjected to friction, like you'd develop if your were rowing

het_1435.pun_sense: colorless gas found in natural gas and petroleum; used as a fuel
het_1435.human_text: Inflammatory talk is often seen as propane language .
het_1435.human_explanation: This is a play on the word "inflammatory," usually meaning violent, but here it also is made to sound like "inflammable," while "propane," which sounds like 'profane," is also inflammable

het_1434.alter_sense: a blood vessel that carries blood from the capillaries toward the heart
het_1434.human_text: ' ' I need an injection , ' ' Tom pleaded in vain .
het_1434.human_explanation:
An injection is the act of administering a liquid into a person's body using a needle. In order to administer the liquid, a vein needs to be found. 
To plead in vain means to plead with no hope in producing a result. Vain is a homophone of vein. A vein is a tube that carries oxygen depleted blood toward the heart. The joke is centered on the word "vain" because it sounds like "vein" and the joke is discussing injections.

het_1433.alter_sense: a ship of the British navy; in 1789 part of the crew mutinied against their commander William Bligh and set him afloat in an open boat
het_1433.human_text: ' ' This is mutiny ! ' ' said Tom bountifully .
het_1433.human_explanation: Poor Tom needs to be incorporated into better jokes. The word 'bountifully' does not refer to the way someone says something, which is why the joke fails.

het_1429.pun_sense: a sheltered port where ships can take on or discharge cargo
het_1429.alter_sense: any place of complete bliss and delight and peace
het_1429.human_text: The port was very beautiful . The sailors said it was haven on earth .
het_1429.human_explanation: In the context of sea, a haven is a place of refuge from the sea, such as a port. Haven on earth sounds like heaven on earth, which is a phrase used to describe a great place.

het_1428.alter_sense: greater in size or importance or degree
het_1428.human_text: I have always wanted to hand out carts at Wal - Mart . I cannot imagine a greeter job .
het_1428.human_explanation: This is a pun on "greeter". They cannot imagine a greater job. Because greater sounds like greeter, and the person is handing out carts at Wal-Mart like a greeter would do, they replaced the word greater with greeter.

het_1427.alter_sense: having or denoting the characteristic taste of sugar
het_1427.human_text: I met a man who loves eating couches . I think he has a suite tooth .
het_1427.human_explanation: A suite is a set of rooms that contain furniture. A couch is a piece of furniture that multiple people can sit on. Suite and sweet are homophones. Sweet is a descriptive word used to describe the taste of something, typically if that something is sugary. If someone has a "sweet tooth" it means they really like and crave eating sweet things. The joke is centered around the word suite and its homophone sweet.

het_1423.human_text: One item contributed was a picture of a pretty , kimono - clad girl ; it bore the inscription : ' ' Maid in Japan ' ' .
het_1423.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words.  Typically on products or decorative pieces there may be written on the item where it was produced, for example it might say 'made in Japan'.  The woman wearing the kimono in the picture may have been a maid, or a house keeper or house cleaner, living in Japan.

het_1422.alter_sense: the sound made by a dog
het_1422.human_text: Did you hear about the vampire who used to torture his victims with music ? His Bach was worse than his bite .
het_1422.human_explanation: This is a play on words. "Bach" is the the name of a famous classical composer but sounds like "bark" as in the famous expression "his bark is worse than his bite" . Vampires are known for biting but since the vampire tortured his victims with music, his "Bach", or the classical music he plays, is worse than his bite.

het_1416.pun_sense: (used in the plural) close-fitting trousers of heavy denim for manual work or casual wear
het_1416.alter_sense: (genetics) a segment of DNA that is involved in producing a polypeptide chain; it can include regions preceding and following the coding DNA as well as introns between the exons; it is considered a unit of heredity
het_1416.human_text: A third - generation clothes designer had it in her jeans .
het_1416.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'jeans', which are just a type of pants but it's usually spelt 'genes' which are the basic physical and functional unit of heredity

het_1412.pun_sense: a spread made chiefly from vegetable oils and used as a substitute for butter
het_1412.alter_sense: a permissible difference; allowing some freedom to move within limits
het_1412.human_text: On cooking shows , there is little margarine of error .
het_1412.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'margine of error' which is a statistic expressing the amount of random sampling error in the results of a survey, but 'margarine' is used in it's place because it sounds somewhat similar and because 'margarine' is a spread used for flavoring, baking and cooking

het_141.pun_sense: ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle
het_141.alter_sense: sign and endorse (another person's signature), as for a loan; sign jointly
het_141.human_text: Some mathematicians are reluctant to cosine a loan .
het_141.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "cosign" means to sign a loan or document jointly with another person. However, "cosign" sounds like "cosine" which is a mathematical term.

het_1406.pun_sense: charge against a citizen's person or property or activity for the support of government; levy a tax on
het_1406.human_text: The IRS left a message on my cell phone that I owed them more money . It was a taxed message .
het_1406.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  The IRS handles taxation.  The words 'tax' and 'text' are similar, so the speaker calls it a 'taxed message' instead of a 'text message' that was sent to their phone.

het_1403.pun_sense: be in accord; be in agreement
het_1403.alter_sense: excessive desire to acquire or possess more (especially more material wealth) than one needs or deserves
het_1403.human_text: I ' ll eat till I burst , Tom agreed .
het_1403.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "agreed" means to express aggreement but "greed" is an intense selfish desire, like the desire to eat until one bursts.

het_1401.pun_sense: have a certain weight; determine the weight of
het_1401.alter_sense: watery part of milk produced when raw milk sours and coagulates; the serum or watery part of milk that is separated from the curd in making cheese
het_1401.human_text: Cottage cheese diet : eating your curds and weigh .
het_1401.human_explanation: Curds are a byproduct of milk that has been coagulated. Curds sit in a liquid called whey. Cottage cheese is a mixture of curds and whey. Weigh and whey are homophones. Weigh is a verb, which is the action taken to figure out how heavy something is, which is an action dieters take often. The joke is talking about a cottage cheese diet, hence the clever use of the word weigh replacing whey.

het_140.pun_sense: the working together of two things (muscles or drugs for example) to produce an effect greater than the sum of their individual effects
het_140.alter_sense: an act that is regarded by theologians as a transgression of God's will; estrangement from god
het_140.human_text: It ' s amazing what two or more sinners can achieve together with synergy .
het_140.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'synergy' which is defined as the interaction or cooperation of two or more organizations, substances, or other agents to produce a combined effect greater than the sum of their separate effects. In this case, the two sinners are the agents, and 'synergy' sounds slightly similar to 'sinners'

het_1396.pun_sense: a public official who investigates by inquest any death not due to natural causes
het_1396.alter_sense: a predicament from which a skillful or graceful escape is impossible
het_1396.human_text: A dying artist painted himself into a coroner .
het_1396.human_explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'painted himself into a corner' which means to put oneself in a bad position, but 'coroner' is used in it's place because it sounds similar and because a 'coroner' is an official who investigates violent, sudden, or suspicious deaths, which is who you'd probably come across if you were dying

het_1395.pun_sense: reproductive organ of angiosperm plants especially one having showy or colorful parts
het_1395.alter_sense: of the color intermediate between green and violet; having a color similar to that of a clear unclouded sky; - Helen Hunt Jackson
het_1395.human_text: At a flower show the first prize is often a bloom ribbon .
het_1395.human_explanation: Bloom is a verb that explains a flower when it is at full maturity and its petals have opened up. Bloom being used here is describing a type of ribbon. The joke is playing on the word bloom and its different applications.

het_1392.pun_sense: a unit of amount of wood cut for burning; 128 cubic feet
het_1392.alter_sense: a combination of three or more notes that blend harmoniously when sounded together
het_1392.human_text: Chop up an old piano and you will get a cord of wood .
het_1392.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'cord' which is a measure of cut wood, but it also works because it sounds similar to 'chord which is a collection of 3 or more notes and is something you could play on a piano

het_1391.pun_sense: the act of propelling with force
het_1391.human_explanation: "Astronauts like to do launch" sounds like "astronauts like to do lunch" which means astronauts like to take lunch. An astronaut is someone trained to travel in a spacecraft. "Launch" is the verb used to describe a spacecraft that is being set in motion to leave Earth and head into outerspace. The joke is centered around the word "launch" which kind of sounds like word "lunch" to describe what astronauts like to do.

het_1390.pun_sense: an elaborate song for solo voice
het_1390.alter_sense: a particular environment or walk of life
het_1390.human_text: Some orchestra conductors make their mark in the world of opera . They were in the right aria at the right time .
het_1390.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'aria' which is a "a long accompanied song for a solo voice, typically one in an opera or oratorio", but it's also being used because it sounds similar to 'area', and the saying would be "in the right area at the right time"

het_1388.pun_sense: form or weave into a braid or braids
het_1388.alter_sense: become weaker; become feeble; lose freshness, vigor, or vitality
het_1388.human_text: OLD HAIRDRESSERS never die , they just braid away . .
het_1388.human_explanation: A hairdresser is someone who cuts and styles hair. To braid hair is to fold three sections of hair over each other repeatedly to create a design. "Braid away" sounds close to "fade away". "Fade away" means gradually become weak, especially to the point of death. The joke is centered around the term "braid away" since it sounds like "fade away" and the joke is explaining what happens to old hairdressers.

het_1385.alter_sense: of a substance, especially a strong acid; capable of destroying or eating away by chemical action
het_1385.human_text: Would you like some soda in your whiskey ? asked Tom caustically .
het_1385.human_explanation: Soda can be considered a caustic, or destructive, substance in some cases.

het_1384.pun_sense: sell or offer for sale from place to place
het_1384.human_text: The store clerk lost his job , so he set up a kiosk in the mall to vend for himself .
het_1384.human_explanation: "Fend for himself" means to do things without help. The store clerk lost his job. "Vend" sounds close to "fend". Vend is used to replace fend because a kiosk can be a vending machine. This joke is playing on the word "vend".

het_1381.pun_sense: the visible disembodied soul of a dead person
het_1381.alter_sense: change location; move, travel, or proceed, also metaphorically
het_1381.human_text: I knew that the spirit couldn ' t float around very long . What ghost up must come down .
het_1381.human_explanation: A spirit is a supernatural being. A ghost is a synonym for spirit. "What ghost up must come down" sounds close to the popular phrase "what goes up must come down". The joke is playing on the word "ghost" because it somewhat sounds like "goes" and can be inserted into the "what goes up must come down" phrase.

het_1380.pun_sense: have sovereign power; be larger in number, quantity, power, status or importance
het_1380.human_text: OLD WEATHERMEN never die , they reign forever .
het_1380.human_explanation: This is the uncommon 'OLD PROFESSIONS' joke that works because it's not trying to be a pun on death. Rather, 'reign forever' implies professional immortality as well as being a pun on 'rain', a type of precipitation that weathermen predict.

het_1378.pun_sense: with boldness, in a bold manner
het_1378.alter_sense: a typeface with thick heavy lines
het_1378.human_text: ' ' I think I ' ll use a different font , ' ' said Tom boldly .
het_1378.human_explanation: Bold is a type of font. Bold also means courage. Boldy means with courage. This is a play on the word bold.

het_1372.pun_sense: a vessel that carries passengers or freight
het_1372.alter_sense: strips of potato fried in deep fat
het_1372.human_text: The Loch Ness monster eats fish and ships .
het_1372.human_explanation: This is a pun on the dish 'fish and chips' which is fried fish and french fries, but 'fish and ships' is used here because it sounds similar and it implies that the loch ness monster eats other fish in the lake as well as boats

het_1371.alter_sense: a relatively thin sheetlike expanse or region lying over or under another
het_1371.human_text: The evil onion had many lairs .
het_1371.human_explanation: This is a pun. An evil lair is a hideout for a villain in a comic book or show. Onions are layered vegetables. The joke is that the onion had many lairs because it was evil.

het_1370.pun_sense: according to what has been alleged
het_1370.alter_sense: a projecting ridge on a mountain or submerged under water
het_1370.human_text: A man threatened to jump off the side of a building - alledgedly .
het_1370.human_explanation: Allegedly has the word alleged in it, which means supposively or uncertain of. Jump of the side of a building might involve jumping off of a ledge.

het_137.human_text: When I phoned my friend yesterday we mainly talked about the weather and our upcomimg exams , and we both agreed that the poring was sickening .
het_137.human_explanation: This is a pun. "Pouring" is frequently used to describe the state of weather during heavy rainfall, when the precipitation is so strong it is as if water is being poured down from a vessel above. "Poring" is a verb referring to consulting written materials in close detail, as in "poring over her notes". The joke subjects are presumably talking about studying for their upcoming exams. The two words are pronounced the same. The play on words here is that it can refer to either the weather or the exams, and that the joke subjects find either or both to be obnoxious.

het_1369.pun_sense: a scar where the umbilical cord was attached
het_1369.alter_sense: connected with or belonging to or used in a navy
het_1369.human_text: The Belly Dancer was popular with sailors because she understood navel maneuvers .
het_1369.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'navel maneuvers' which is referring to tasks relating to those in the navy, and it also being used because 'navel' is another term for belly button which is most prominent on belly dancers

het_1368.pun_sense: a person who professes beliefs and opinions that he or she does not hold in order to conceal his or her real feelings or motives
het_1368.alter_sense: any of various breeds of small gentle horses usually less than five feet high at the shoulder; a range horse of the western United States
het_1368.human_text: She thought it was a real horse , but it was a phony .
het_1368.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words.  A 'phony' is another word for a fake or fraud.  'Phony' sounds like 'pony' which is the name of a young horse.

het_1363.pun_sense: utter or proclaim insistently and noisily
het_1363.alter_sense: burrowing marine mollusk living on sand or mud; the shell closes with viselike firmness
het_1363.human_text: Another batch of shells for me ! Tom clamored .
het_1363.human_explanation: A shell is a hard outer covering of an animal. A clam is a type of mollusk, and contains a shell. To clamor is to proclaim loudly. The joke is centered on the word "clamored" and how it relates to "clam" which is a type of shell.

het_1359.pun_sense: a very wealthy or powerful businessman
het_1359.alter_sense: (physics) a device that attracts iron and produces a magnetic field
het_1359.human_text: George Westinghouse was a refrigerator magnate .
het_1359.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "magnate" means a wealthy, influential person in business but "magnate" sounds like "magnet" which is an object that can stick to other metal objects. Magnets are commonly stuck to refrigerator doors, so the joke here Is that Westinghouse is a refrigerator magnate/magnet since his company made refrigerators.

het_1354.pun_sense: more than is needed, desired, or required
het_1354.alter_sense: a conduit to carry off smoke
het_1354.human_explanation: A chimney flu is the part that opens the vent.

het_1349.pun_sense: a very wealthy or powerful businessman
het_1349.alter_sense: (physics) a device that attracts iron and produces a magnetic field
het_1349.human_text: Many people are strongly attracted to a magnate .
het_1349.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "magnate". A "magnate" is a wealthy or influential person, the kind of person people are attracted to in the sense that they want to have a close relationship with them. "Magnate" sounds like "magnet". Magnets also attract things, but in a physical way.

het_1346.pun_sense: important food fish on both sides of the Atlantic; related to cod but usually smaller; lean white flesh of fish similar to but smaller than cod; usually baked or poached or as fillets sauteed or fried
het_1346.alter_sense: pain in the head caused by dilation of cerebral arteries or muscle contractions or a reaction to drugs
het_1346.human_text: A fisherman took pain pills because of a persistent haddock .
het_1346.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. 'Haddock' is a type of fish, and sounds like 'headache' which is a pain in the head that one might take pain relieving pills for.

het_1342.pun_sense: to an ample degree or in an ample manner
het_1342.alter_sense: the basic unit of electric current adopted under the Systeme International d'Unites
het_1342.human_text: ' ' It ' s a unit of electric current , ' ' said Tom amply .
het_1342.human_explanation: Amply means more than enough, or sufficiently. An amp is the base unit of an electric current. We see "amp" in amply.

het_1340.pun_sense: the chair of state for a monarch, bishop, etc.; put a monarch on the throne; sit on the throne as a ruler
het_1340.alter_sense: get rid of; get rid of; throw or cast away
het_1340.human_text: OLD KINGS never die they just get throne away
het_1340.human_explanation: "Throne away" sounds like "thrown away" which means to toss in the garbage. A throne is a seat designated to someone in power, it is where they sit. A king, which is a person with power, sits on a throne. This joke is a play on the word throne.

het_1336.pun_sense: a nuclear reaction in which a massive nucleus splits into smaller nuclei with the simultaneous release of energy
het_1336.alter_sense: catch or try to catch fish or shellfish; the act of someone who fishes as a diversion
het_1336.human_text: The nuclear physicist took a vacation for a fission trip .
het_1336.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'fission' which is a reaction in which the nucleus of an atom splits into two or more smaller nuclei, but it's being used here because it sounds like 'fishing trip' which is what some people might take a vacation for

het_1335.pun_sense: express the same message in different words
het_1335.alter_sense: a recompense for worthy acts or retribution for wrongdoing
het_1335.human_text: A pun is its own reword .
het_1335.human_explanation: The joke is a pun on the word 'reword'.  The phrase is typically 'it's own reward' but the word 'reward' was replaced with 'reword'.  A pun 'rewords' or rephrases or replaces a word in the sentence to make a joke, in the attempt that the word replaced was something clever for sounding similar or having a double meaning.

het_1332.alter_sense: a person or thing that is a resource that helps make something easier or possible to do; the activity of contributing to the fulfillment of a need or furtherance of an effort or purpose
het_1332.human_text: People in Switzerland can ' t learn to ski without a lot of alp .
het_1332.human_explanation: The Alps are an extensive mountain range that runs through Switzerland. You can ski on The Alps.  "Alp" kind of sounds like "help".  The joke is centered on the word "alp" and how it sounds like "help".

het_133.human_text: To learn rope tricks you have to be taut .
het_133.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'taught' which means show or explain to (someone) how to do something, but 'taut' is used in it's place because it sounds similar and it means stretched or pulled tight; not slack, like rope can be

het_1329.alter_sense: the person or thing chosen or selected
het_1329.human_text: An argument over puppy selection is a pique of the litter .
het_1329.human_explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'pick of the litter' which is the best one of a group. However, 'pique' is used in it's place because it sounds similar and because 'pique' means a feeling of irritation or resentment resulting from a slight, especially to one's pride, like what you'd feel if you gotten into an argument

het_1328.pun_sense: talk indistinctly; usually in a low voice; make complaining remarks or noises under one's breath
het_1328.alter_sense: an inferior dog or one of mixed breed
het_1328.human_text: That ' s no beagle ; that ' s a mongrel , Tom muttered .
het_1328.human_explanation: A beagle is a type of dog. A mongrel is a dog that results from the crossing of different breeds. To mutter is to say something in a low or barely audible voice. A mutt is a dog, another word for mongrel. We see "mutt" in "muttered". The joke is centered around the word "muttered" because we can see the word "mutt" in it and the joke is about dogs.

het_1327.pun_sense: in an obnoxious manner; in an unpleasantly offensive manner
het_1327.alter_sense: a dealer in stolen property; receive stolen goods
het_1327.human_text: ' ' Do you buy and sell stolen goods ? ' ' asked Tom offensively .
het_1327.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  Buying and selling stolen goods is illegal and police and courts would mark any instance of that as an 'offense' against the law.  To do or say something 'offensively' is to do it in an actively aggressive or attacking manner.

het_1322.alter_sense: a streak of light in the sky at night that results when a meteoroid hits the earth's atmosphere and air friction causes the meteoroid to melt or vaporize or explode; (astronomy) any of the small solid extraterrestrial bodies that hits the earth's atmosphere
het_1322.human_text: An explosion at the meat packing plant caused quite a meatier shower .
het_1322.human_explanation: A pun on "meteor shower", when small celestial objects enter Earth's atmosphere en masse and burn up visible to the naked eye. An explosion at a meat packing plant causing large quantities of meat to be propelled high into the air would result in said meat "showering" down.

het_1319.alter_sense: a part of a river where the current is very fast
het_1319.human_text: Have you ever been whitewater rafting ? Tom asked rapidly .
het_1319.human_explanation: The joke is a pun on the word 'rapidly'. Whitewater rafting is rafting on the rapids of a river.  To say something 'rapidly' is to say it really fast.

het_1316.pun_sense: grains of common wheat; sometimes cooked whole or cracked as cereal; usually ground into flour; annual or biennial grass having erect flower spikes and light brown grains
het_1316.human_text: Farmers can hardly wheat for a good harvest .
het_1316.human_explanation: "Wheat" sounds a little bit like "wait". The farmers can hardly wait for a good harvest. Wheat is a cereal plant that farmers grow. This joke is playing on the word wheat, using it to replace wait.

het_1312.pun_sense: Augustinian monk and botanist whose experiments in breeding garden peas led to his eventual recognition as founder of the science of genetics (1822-1884)
het_1312.alter_sense: restore by replacing a part or putting together what is torn or broken
het_1312.human_text: The geneticist taught his students how to mendel defective genes .
het_1312.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'mend' which means to repair something, but 'mendel' is used in it's place because it sounds similar and because it's the name of Gregor Mendel who was a biologist

het_1311.pun_sense: manually manipulate (someone's body), usually for medicinal or relaxation purposes
het_1311.human_text: A massage therapist kneaded new customers .
het_1311.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. Kneading is using hands and applying pressure to something, typically dough, but one could say that when a massage therapist is applying pressure on someone's body, they are kneading it.  'Kneaded' sounds identical to 'needed', so it is used instead of the 'needed' that means 'required' or 'mandatory'.

het_1310.pun_sense: a framework of beams (rafters, posts, struts) forming a rigid structure that supports a roof or bridge or other structure
het_1310.alter_sense: a trustful relationship; the trait of believing in the honesty and reliability of others; complete confidence in a person or plan etc
het_1310.human_text: I don ' t recommend dating bridge builders , they have truss issues .
het_1310.human_explanation: The joke is a play on words. Builders or engineers construct with a variety of shapes that have different levels of structural integrity, with one of them being called a 'truss'.  'Truss' sounds like 'trust', so it sounds like builders have 'trust issues'.

het_1305.pun_sense: be a mystery or bewildering to
het_1305.alter_sense: become covered with mist; spray finely or cover with mist
het_1305.human_text: The first scientists who studied fog were mistified .
het_1305.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. 'Mistified' means bewildered or perplexed.  The word has 'mist' in it, and mist is moisture in the air like a cloud or fog.

het_1304.pun_sense: inflammation of the nose and throat with increased production of mucus
het_1304.alter_sense: an Arab country on the peninsula of Qatar; achieved independence from the United Kingdom in 1971; the economy is dominated by oil
het_1304.human_text: My chronically runny - nosed friend , who staunchly opposes all independent emirates , was bothered by catarrh on his trip around the world .
het_1304.human_explanation: Most people don't know what a catarrh is in the US. It even took me a moment to understand that it served as a homonym for 'Qatar' - a Middle Eastern country.

het_1302.pun_sense: any of several small gregarious cetacean mammals having a blunt snout and many teeth
het_1302.alter_sense: an anticipated outcome that is intended or that guides your planned actions; what something is used for
het_1302.human_text: The marine biology seminars weren ' t for entertainment , but were created for educational porpoises .
het_1302.human_explanation: "Porpoises" sounds like "purposes". "Educational purposes" is a common saying, meaning that something is for learning. A porpoise is an aquatic marine mammal. Marine biology is the study of living creatures in the sea.  The joke is playing on the term "educational purposes" but using "porpoises" to replace "purposes" because marine biology seminars is what is getting discussed.

het_1301.alter_sense: a superior skill that you can learn by study and practice and observation
het_1301.human_text: Romance isn ' t a science - it ' s a heart .
het_1301.human_explanation: The text references categorizing something as science or an art. The subject is romance, which hs known to be a matter of the heart. The word heart is used to replace art.

het_1299.pun_sense: something used to lure fish or other animals into danger so they can be trapped or killed; lure, entice, or entrap with bait
het_1299.alter_sense: moderate or restrain; lessen the force of; diminished or moderated
het_1299.human_text: After Jimmy swallowed a live earthworm , he sat waiting with baited breath to see if he ' d get sick .
het_1299.human_explanation: The joke is a pun.  The word 'baited' was used instead for the phrase 'bated breath'.  'Bated breath' means in great suspense, very anxiously, or excitedly. 'Bait' or 'baited' are words that would refer to bait for fishing, such as live worms.

het_1298.pun_sense: one of the 150 lyrical poems and prayers that comprise the Book of Psalms in the Old Testament; said to have been written by David
het_1298.alter_sense: the inner surface of the hand from the wrist to the base of the fingers
het_1298.human_text: Anxious about the future ? Psalms read every Sunday .
het_1298.human_explanation: This is a pun on 'psalms' which is the book of the Old Testament composed of sacred songs, or of sacred poems meant to be sung, so this is associated with Sundays and church. But 'psalms' also sounds similar to 'palm' which is what you get read if you wanted to know about your future

het_1297.pun_sense: a title given to rulers or other important people in Asian countries
het_1297.alter_sense: a swindle in which you cheat at gambling or persuade a person to buy worthless property; a person serving a sentence in a jail or prison
het_1297.human_text: Remembering the Mongol leader ' s reputation for chicanery , Marco Polo approached the palace of the khan warily .
het_1297.human_explanation: This is a pun on the word "khan". A "khan" is a Mongol ruler. It sounds like "con", which is when you trick someone. This joke is about a Mongol ruler who is known to trick people.

het_1295.pun_sense: an opening deliberately made in or through something
het_1295.alter_sense: including all components without exception; being one unit or constituting the full amount or extent or duration; complete
het_1295.human_text: A baker stopped making donuts after he got tired of the hole thing .
het_1295.human_explanation: The joke is a pun. Donuts are pastries that have a hole in the center of them. To be tired of 'the whole thing' is to be completely fed up with the entirety of something, however it sounds like the baker is just tired of the holes in the centers of donuts.

het_1292.pun_sense: become smaller; decrease in phase; grow smaller
het_1292.human_text: The sun was bright on a dry , cloudless morning , but later it waned .
het_1292.human_explanation: This is a play on words. The word "waned" means became weaker but "waned" also refers to when the sun or moon has a progressively smaller part of their visible surface illuminated.

het_1291.pun_sense: the helmsman of a ship's boat or a racing crew
het_1291.human_text: The eight chicken farmers jumped in their rowing shell and put their cox up in front .
het_1291.human_explanation: cox' is short for coxswain, or the individual at the head of a boat that directs the others. It's also a play on 'cocks' - slang for roosters.

het_1290.pun_sense: feel remorse for; feel sorry for; be contrite about
het_1290.alter_sense: lacking civility or good manners; - Willa Cather; socially incorrect in behavior
het_1290.human_text: I really regretted the inconsiderate comment I made . It was rued .
het_1290.human_explanation: Rued means to regret something. Rued sounds like rude. Here, the person is saying they regret their inconsierate comment which could be considered rude, but the word rued was used instead.

het_1289.pun_sense: a printed picture produced from a photographic negative
het_1289.alter_sense: a male member of a royal family other than the sovereign (especially the son of a sovereign)
het_1289.human_text: Waiting for her photos to be developed a young girl sang ' Some day my prints will come . '
het_1289.human_explanation: Prints sounds like "prince". "Someday my prince will come" are the title and lyrics to a song sung in the movie Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. In photography negatives are used to produce postive prints on paper, which is the photo. The whole joke circles around print.

het_1286.alter_sense: the leader of an Arab village or family
het_1286.human_text: The Arab ' s opulence was obvious from his chic clothing . ' '
het_1286.human_explanation: Sheikh is a homophone of chic. A sheikh is an Arab leader. "Chic" clothing refers to clothing that is stylish. Opulence means a lot of wealth, so the joke is saying the Arab is wealthy and we can tell by his chic clothing. The joke is playing on the word "chic" in "chic clothing" because it sounds like "sheikh".

het_1283.pun_sense: one of the tendons at the back of the knee
het_1283.alter_sense: meat cut from the thigh of a hog (usually smoked)
het_1283.human_text: Why did the pig quit running the marathon ? He had a problem with his hamstring .
het_1283.human_explanation: The hamstring is a muscle that runs down the back of the thigh. Ham is meat from the upper part of a pig's leg. The word "ham" can be found in "hamstring" and the joke is referring to a pig that quit running a marathon due to a hamstring injury.

het_1276.pun_sense: a piece of poetry; literature in metrical form
het_1276.alter_sense: something inferior in quality or condition or effect
het_1276.human_text: She was only a Poet ' s daughter , but I ' ve seen verse .
het_1276.human_explanation: A verse is a collection of lines in a poem. Verse also sounds like "worse". "I've seen verse" sounds like "I've seen worse" regarding the poet's daughter.

het_1275.pun_sense: gossip (usually a mixture of truth and untruth) passed around by word of mouth
het_1275.alter_sense: the trait of appreciating (and being able to express) the humorous
het_1275.human_text: A gossip is someone with a great sense of rumor .
het_1275.human_explanation: This is a play on words. Sense of humor means that someone knows what's funny but also sounds like "sense of rumor" and rumors are circulating stories spread by gossips.

het_1273.pun_sense: a native of inhabitant of the Czech Republic
het_1273.alter_sense: announce one's departure from a hotel
het_1273.human_text: OLD SLAVS never die , they just czech out .
het_1273.human_explanation: Czech is a Slavic language, and members of the family of Slavic ethnic groups are commonly referred to as "Slavs". This is a pun on "check out", because common English pronunciation of "Czech" is identical to "check".

het_1271.pun_sense: a restraint used to slow or stop a vehicle; cause to stop by applying the brakes; stop travelling by applying a brake
het_1271.human_text: When people first heard of the ABS , it was braking news .
het_1271.human_explanation: The anti-lock brake system, or ABS, is a relatively new technology in a car. 'braking news' is also a pun on 'breaking news' used because ABS is one letter short of ABC: American Broadcasting Corporation.

het_1265.pun_sense: a Tibetan or Mongolian priest of Lamaism
het_1265.alter_sense: wild or domesticated South American cud-chewing animal related to camels but smaller and lacking a hump
het_1265.human_text: Throughout the centuries , the Buddhist herdsmen of Peru have followed their lamas religiously .
het_1265.human_explanation:
Lama in Tibetan buddhism means spiritual leader. 
A llama is an animal that can be found in Peru. Llama and lama sound the same but mean different things. The buddhists following their lamas can sound like the buddhists are following their llamas (or animals).

het_1264.alter_sense: ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle
